questions.text:
As seen in the image, a 25-year-old woman arrived with erythematous papules on her face. Excessive perspiration, exposure to the sun,
and emotional distress all made the lesions worse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis of this 25-year-old girl with erythematous papules on the face as seen in the picture with exacerbated lesions on excessive sweating, sun exposure and emotional disturbance is acne rosacea.
  • Acne rosacea is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the face, particularly the cheeks, nose, chin, and forehead.
  • It is characterized by redness, flushing, and the appearance of papules and pustules. The condition is often worsened by triggers such as sun exposure, emotional stress, and alcohol consumption.
  • Photodermatitis is a skin reaction that occurs after exposure to sunlight and is characterized by redness, itching, and blisters, but it does not usually present with papules.
  • SLE is close differential , but it has other systemic features with sparing of Nasolabial folds.
  • Below is an image of Lupus Rash vs  Rosacea. Note the sparing of the nasolabial folds.




Reference- Illustrated Synopsis of Dermatology and Sexually Transmitted Diseases, Neena Khanna, 4th edition, page number 121, 122.

questions.text: Panniculus adiposus can be found in
questions.solution:
• Panniculus adiposus is a layer of subcutaneous fat found in the skin of mammals. It is responsible for insulation, protection, and energy storage and is present all over the body.
  • It is not found in Eyelid, nipple,Scrotum(has dartos muscles) or Penis(has colles fascia)
Reference: https://ifaa.unifr.ch/Public/EntryPage/TA98%20Tree/Entity%20TA98%20EN/16.0.03.001%20Entity%20TA98%20EN.htm

questions.text: What does a Malpighian layer consist of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Spinosum and Basale
 
  • The malpighian layer of the epidermis includes both Stratum Basale and Stratum Spinosum as a unit.
  • It is named after Marcello Malpighi.
Layers of epidermis of skin (superficial to deep):
  
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 2.5

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone used in cosmetics as:
questions.solution:
• Methylisothiazolinone is used as a preservative in cosmetics.
  • Methylisothiazolinone forms an important component of everyday cosmetic products.
  • It is added to cosmetics to prevent the growth of bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms that can cause spoilage or contamination.
  • It can cause Allergic Contact Dermatitis. 
 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 128.36

questions.text: Identify the following lines in dermatology
questions.solution:
The above image shows Blaschko lines as identified by the spiraling over the scalp. Blaschko‘s lines are lines of normal developmental growth patterns in the skin. They do not correspond to any known nervous, vascular, or lymphatic structures. Conditions that are distributed along these lines include epidermal nevi, and incontinentiapigmenti.



Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 7.7,20.1 .

questions.text: A patient arrived with a 7-day history of bullae covering more than 30% of the body's surface area as well as erosions of the lips and other mucosae. What is the likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
• The above picture shows a forearm with extensive reddish bullae involving >30% body surface area and the description is typical of the spectrum of Steven-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), is a rare, life-threatening skin condition that is usually caused by a reaction to drugs.
  • SJS/TEN is a rare, but potentially life-threatening, hypersensitivity reaction to certain medications and less commonly infections more commonly viral infections 
  • It is characterized by the formation of painful bullae, erosions, and ulcerations of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • The condition typically presents within the first few weeks of starting a new medication, although it can occur at any time during treatment. Many medications have been associated with SJS, including antibiotics (e.g., sulfonamides), anticonvulsants (e.g., phenytoin), and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (e.g., ibuprofen).
  • The exact mechanism of SJS is not fully understood, but it is thought to be a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which involves activation of T-cells and subsequent release of cytokines.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.13

questions.text: As shown in the picture, a patient presented with itchy, tight blisters on both healthy skin and over urticarial plaques. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis in this patient with tense blisters on normal-looking skin-associated urticaria/ plaques as seen in the figure points towards a diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid.
  • The blisters can occur on healthy skin or over urticarial plaques, which are raised, itchy patches of skin. The blisters are typically itchy and can be painful.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris typically affects the mucous membranes rather than the skin.
  • Linear IgA disease typically affects the skin around the mouth, eyes, and genitals.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis causes itchy, blistering rashes, but it is typically associated with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease.



PV- Pemphigus vulgaris
PF- Pemphigus foliaceus 
EBA-Epidermolysis bullosa Acquisita
Pveg- Pemphigus Vegetans 







Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.10

questions.text: The figure depicts a 65-year-old man who has tense blisters and itching on otherwise normal-appearing skin with urticarial plaques. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical description fits with that of Bullous pemphigoid.
  • Bullous pemphigoid is an subepidermal immunobullous disorder that affects older age groups leading to blisters/ bullae on urticated as well as normal looking skin and associated pruritus.
  • Antibodies are formed against hemidesmosomal proteins [ BP antigen 230 (BPAG1) & BP antigen 180 (BPAG2 Or Type XVII Collagen)]
  • These antibodies cause damage to dermo-epidermal junction leading to a sub-epidermal split in the skin.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.10

questions.text: A middle-aged woman went to the emergency department with severe blisters on her skin and oral mucosa. The following is an example of direct immunofluorescence. All the following are accurate regarding the disease pathogenesis except
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Fishnet Immunofluorescence seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris.
  • Antibodies against desmogleins 1 and 3 found in desmosomes are the cause of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Anti-Desmoglein 3 levels are thought to be closely correlated with the disease severity and the presence of mucosal lesions.
  • Pemphigus in its milder variants is more anti-desmoglein 1 heavy.
  • Anti-hemidesmosome antibodies are seen in Bullous Pemphigoid. 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

questions.text: The following histological picture of a patient's skin sample suggests:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pemphigus Vulgaris
  • The image shows the suprabasal acantholysis seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune skin disorder with IgG antibodies against desmoglein (a component of desmosomes, which connect keratinocytes in the stratum spinosum).
  • Flaccid intraepidermal bullae can be caused by acantholysis (separation of keratinocytes, resembling a “row of tombstones”).
  • It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Immunofluorescence reveals antibodies around epidermal cells in a reticular (fishnet-like) pattern
  • Nikolsky sign will be positive. (separation of epidermis upon manual stroking of skin).


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.6

questions.text:
A patient with a history of bullae involving >30% BSA, rashes all over the body, and temporary mucosal erosions on the lips and other areas.
What might operate as the most likely trigger?
questions.solution:
• A history of bullae involving more than 30% of the body surface area associated with rashes all over the body and erosions of the lips and mucosa at other sites for a few days is suggestive of drug-induced eruptions.
  • These kinds of descriptions are characteristic of the spectrum of toxic epidermal necrolysis and Steven-Johnson syndrome.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.13

questions.text: In a superficial partial-thickness burn, which layer is involved in blister formation?
questions.solution:
The American Burn Association (ABA) has published an educational resource that reviewed the classification and management of the burn wound. The classification system below is largely in agreement.
  • Superficial Burns
A superficial (first-degree) burn involves the epidermis only. These burns can be pink-to-red, without blistering, are dry, and can be moderately painful. Superficial burns heal without scarring within 5 to 10 days.
 
  • Partial-Thickness Burns

A second-degree burn, also known as a superficial partial-thickness burn, affects the superficial layer of the dermis (Papillary dermis). Blisters are common and may still be intact when first evaluated. Once the blister is unroofed, the underlying wound bed is homogeneously red or pink and will blanch with pressure. These burns are painful. Healing typically occurs within 2 to 3 weeks with minimal scarring.

A deep partial-thickness burn involves the deeper reticular dermis, can also present with intact blisters. Once the blisters are debrided, the underlying wound bed is mottled and will sluggishly blanch with pressure. The patient with a partial-thickness burn experiences minimal pain, which may only be present with deep pressure. These burns can heal without surgery, but it takes longer, and scarring is unavoidable.
 
  • Full-Thickness Burns

A third-degree burn, also known as a full-thickness burn, is most severe and affects the epidermis and dermis skin layers. They also extend into the subcutaneous tissue. These burns result in a leathery, stiff, and dry appearance. At this depth, the affected area does not blanch under pressure due to compromised blood supply. The nerves at this depth are also damaged, resulting in the patient experiencing no sensation or pain. These burns take more than 8 weeks to heal and require surgical treatment.



Reference- Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no 669

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with uncomfortable blisters over her vaginal and oral mucosa. She described the prior occurrences of corresponding lesions. On histology, a biopsy taken from the lesion revealed a suprabasal split. Intercellular IgG deposits were discovered using immunofluorescence microscopy, as seen below. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The figure shows a direct immunofluorescence image revealing fishnet pattern with intercellular deposition of IgG against Desmoglein 1 & 3, classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The clinico-immunofluorescence co-relation in the above patient confirms the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.


AIBD- Autoimmune Blistering Disorder
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

choices.text: Linear IgA deposition in the dermo-epidermal junction
Linear IgG deposition in the dermo-epidermal junction
Granular deposits of IgA in dermal papillae

questions.text: Flaccid bullae with an erythematous foundation and erosions over the oral mucosal membrane are seen in a 30-year-old male patient. What would the immunofluorescent study of this patient's skin biopsy most likely reveal?
questions.solution:
• Flaccid bullae with an erythematous foundation and erosions over the oral mucosal membrane point towards a diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Fishnet IgG deposition in the epidermis is seen in the case of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Biopsy typically shows acantholysis  and an intraepidermal blister.

Fish net appearance in DIF. 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2, 50.8

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with multiple painful blisters on an erythematous base along the T3 dermatome on the trunk. Which of the following etiological agent is most likely to be implicated?
questions.solution:
• Varicella zoster or shingles is a condition characterized by painful, unilateral vesicular eruptions that occur in a single dermatome, usually on the T3 to L3 area.
  • The prodromal phase of segmental pain preceding the eruption typically starts 1-4 days before its appearance.
  • Edema and erythema are quickly followed by the tuft of vesicles. In some cases, the mucous membranes within the dermatome may also be involved
  • Herpes simplex virus typically causes painful vesicular lesions on the lips or genital area, but it does not follow a dermatomal distribution.
  • Human papilloma virus  causes warts, which are typically painless and do not follow a dermatomal distribution.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.27

questions.text: A 60 years old man presented with itchy tense blisters on normal looking skin and urticarial rash. Investigation done for the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Features are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid and diagnosis can be done by DIF.  DIF can be used to detect antibodies to different components of the skin, such as the basement membrane zone or desmoglein.
  • These antibodies are present in the majority of individuals with pemphigoid and can be detected by fluorescent staining techniques.
  • Additionally, DIF can also be used to distinguish between other autoimmune skin diseases such as epidermolysis bullosa acquisita  or lichen planus, which may have similar clinical features to pemphigoid.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

questions.text: n adult female patient arrives with buccal mucosa ulcers as well as flaccid blisters on the trunk and back that take a very long time to cure. The Tzanck smear is favourable. Specify Dx
questions.solution:
• The given clinical diagnosis of flaccid epidermal blisters involving skin and oral mucosa along with acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear goes in favor of Pemphigus Vulgaris.
  • Below is an approach to diagnosing different pemphigus disorders

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: A subepidermal blister containing neutrophils. The recommended treatment among the given options  is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is dermatitis herpetiformis for which Dapsone is the treatment of choice.

Dapsone inhibits neutrophil migration thus is the DOC in Dermatitis Herpetiformis. 

Causes of Subepidermal blisters are:
  • Bulbous pemphigoid
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Pseudoporphyria
  • Linear IgA dermatosis
  • Herpes gestationis
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.54

questions.text: The limbs of a 68-year-old patient had itchy, tense skin blisters on the extensor aspect, as depicted below. What would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows tense bullae on urticarial red base which are most likely due to bullous pemphigoid.
  • It is an immunobullous disorder where antibodies are directed against BPAG - 2 and BPAG - 1 present in hemidesmosomes.
    There is sub - epidermal split in the skin resulting in formation of tense bullae which have red, urticarial bases. Histopathology shows sub - epidermal bullae with eosinophils.
  • Direct immunofluorescence study shows a linear pattern of IgG, C3 deposition in the basement membrane zone.

Treatment— steroids.

Below is an image which can be used to diagnose different Bullous conditions based on the keywords

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: When exposed to friction, a male infant born to a non-consanguineous spouse develops rashes. A kid born to a couple with a similar issue passed away a few days after one week of life. What is the condition?
questions.solution:
This condition is epidermolysis bullosa.

Epidermolysis bullosa is a rare condition that causes fragile, blistering skin.
The blisters may appear in response to mechanical trauma like minor injury, even from heat, rubbing or scratching.
In severe cases, the blisters may occur inside the body, such as the lining of the mouth or stomach. 
Death is inevitable in severe forms
Below is classification of different forms of EB.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.41

questions.text:
Skin lesion are present on the patient. A biopsy was performed, and the lesion's histopathology is displayed.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. From the provided histology image we can observe there is a suprabasilar blister, a portion of the epidermis, including the stratum corneum, forms the roof which is normally seen in Pemphigus vulgaris
  2. The various hpe features of Pemphigus Vulgaris include 
  • Acantholysis: Loss of cell-to-cell adhesion between keratinocytes.
  • Suprabasal blister: Separation just above the basal layer of the epidermis.
  • Tombstone appearance: Basal keratinocytes remain attached to the basement membrane, resembling tombstones. 
  • Direct immunofluorescence (DIF): IgG and C3 deposits in a “fishnet” or “chicken wire” pattern between keratinocytes.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: In which case is intra-epidermal intercellular deposition of IgG on immunofluorescence most common?
questions.solution:
Intra-epidermal intercellular deposition of IgG on immunofluorescence is seen in Pemphigus.
  • It is an autoimmune disease characterized by acantholysis induced by the deposition of lgG antibodies in the intercellular area of the epidermis.
  • The commonest variant of pemphigus is Pemphigus vulgaris, seen in adults mainly.
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis is a rare neutrophilic dermatosis with sterile pustules in subcorneal level. 




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: A 50 y patient has an oral ulcers and skin bullae that are taking their time to heal. Where exactly is the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The lesion is suprabasal.
  • A 50-year-old patient with bulla on his body and oral mucosa with the given image likely has pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Bulla in pemphigus vulgaris is intra-epidermal and the split is suprabasal.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: The following is implicated in the pathogenesis of toxic epidermal necrolysis [TEN]:
questions.solution:
The correct option is (1).
  • Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.
  • SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).
  • The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are Carbamazepine, lamotrigine, allopurinol, oxicam, NSAIDs, phenytoin, sulfa drugs, etc. 
  • The majority of the Carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis CBZ-SJS/TEN are associated with HLA-B*15:02.
  • HLA-B57 and HLA-B58 have not been consistently associated with an increased risk for SJS/TEN
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.14

questions.text: What causes the contact dermatitis referred to as "Scourge of India"?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Parthenium
 
  • Parthenium or Gajar Ghans is the most common invasive species in India. It is called as the “Scourge of India", scourge meaning something that causes great trouble or suffering.
  • In India, the weed Parthenium most commonly causes airborne dermatitis.
  • Many allergenic plants, especially those belonging to the Compositae (Asteraceae) family, are destroyed by cold and frosty weather, but return during the warmer spring and summer months. 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 128.11

questions.text: Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris is distinguished by antibodies against?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Desmoglein 1 and 3
 
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucosa.
  • In the skin, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers.
  • In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present in lower layers.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: A patient with history of skin lesions underwent the following test. Identify the test given below.?
questions.solution:
Direct immunofluorescence is used in diagnosis of autoimmune blistering disease such as pemphigus.
In DIF antibodies are directly applied to skin biopsy specimen. If patient has Pemphigus, the antibodies will bind to desmosomes producing a fish net pattern.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No: 50.8.

questions.text: 50 y old lady presents with oral ulcers and bullae over skin and mucosa. On examination the bullae were flaccid and filled with clear fluid. HPE is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given HPE shows suprabasal splitting of epidermis [acantholysis] giving rise to the row of tombstone appearance suggestive of Pemphigus Vulgaris.
Autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1 and 3 are present.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 50.7

questions.text: A young female presented with the following findings on the face. Which among the following will not be useful for its treatment?
questions.solution:
The patient has acne vulgaris, which typically presents with comedones, papules, pustules, and sometimes nodules.

  • Effective treatments for acne include:

    • Topical benzoyl peroxide: Reduces bacteria and has mild comedolytic effect.

    • Topical retinoids: Normalize follicular keratinization and prevent comedone formation.

    • Topical antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin, erythromycin): Reduce Cutibacterium acnes and inflammation. 

  • Topical corticosteroids (fluocinolone):

    • Not useful for acne; can worsen acne by causing steroid-induced acne (comedones and papules).

Key point:

Topical steroids are contraindicated in acne treatment.

choices.text: Statement 1 is true and Statement 2 is false
Statement 1 is false and Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true, and Statement 2 is the conclusion of Statement 1
Both statements are true, but Statement 2 is not the conclusion of Statement 1

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct?
Statement 1: Histopathological examination of a patient with flaccid bullae and painful erosions reveals a suprabasal blister with inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft.
Statement 2: A row of tombstones appearance is characteristic of Pemphigus vulgaris.
questions.solution:
Both statements 1 and 2 are correct; however, statement 2 is not derived as the conclusion of statement 1. This is because a definitive diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris requires direct immunofluorescence (DIF).

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disorder caused by antibodies targeting desmosomal proteins in the skin and mucosa.
  • In the skin, desmoglein 1 is predominantly expressed in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more concentrated in the lower layers. Conversely, in the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is expressed throughout all layers, and desmoglein 1 is present in the lower layers.
 
  • Clinically, patients present with irregular, slow-healing oral lesions and erosions.
  • Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may form on normal or erythematous skin.
  • These blisters rupture easily, leading to painful erosions that heal without scarring. The disease can also affect other mucosal sites, including the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, esophagus, urethra, vulva, and cervix.
 
  • Nikolsky's sign is typically positive, elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure on affected or surrounding skin.
  • This pressure causes separation of the epidermis, forming erosions.

Supra-basal split:



Row of tombstone appearance:




Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 50.1-50.5 .

questions.text: A patient on Anti PD1 immunotherapy(Nivolumab) comes with pruritus, eczema, and urticarial rashes. Histopathological examination reveals a subepidermal blister. The direct Immunofluorescence of the lesions showed Linear C3 and IgG on the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, a history of using anti-programmed cell death 1 (PD1) targeted immune checkpoint inhibitors, along with histopathological examination showing a subepidermal split, and direct immunofluorescence revealing linear deposits of C3 and IgG at the basement membrane, is suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.
 
  • PD1 inhibitors, such as nivolumab and pembrolizumab, are associated with an increased risk of developing bullous pemphigoid. Histopathology typically shows subepidermal bullae containing eosinophils. Immunofluorescence microscopy confirms the presence of subepidermal splitting and deposits of IgG antibodies and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction.
 
  • Bullous pemphigoid is one of the most common subepidermal immunobullous disorders, predominantly affecting the elderly. It is characterized by a subepidermal split, with tissue-bound and serum IgG antibodies targeting BP180 more than BP230 antigens located on hemidesmosomes, which are critical for maintaining skin structure.
 
  • Bullous pemphigoid has associations with psoriasis, including its treatments like phototherapy and psoralen. It is also linked to neurological conditions such as stroke, Parkinson‘s disease, cognitive impairment, and multiple sclerosis, as well as hematological malignancies.



Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 50.1-50.22, 50.52-50.55.

questions.text: Celiac disease is associated with which of the following skin conditions
questions.solution: Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, autoimmune, blistering disease that causes a symmetric extremely pruritic rash that predominantly affects the extensor surfaces. Dermatitis herpetiformis also known as Duhring's disease is an autoimmune disease associated with HLA DQ-2 and HLA DQ-8. The disease is closely associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (GSE); both conditions are characterized by the development of IgA autoantibodies against transglutaminases which, in the case of dermatitis herpetiformis, are deposited in the superficial papillary dermis. Characteristic histopathology finding is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils.Ref- Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page 50.54

questions.text: A woman complained of a bluish lesion across the left side of the forehead and left eye when she arrived. An irregular bluish lesion is detected in the left superior conjunctiva and forehead. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given picture shows an irregular bluish lesion in the left superior maxillary and ophthalmic region of trigeminal nerve in a female patient. The most probable diagnosis is Nevus of Ota.
  • It is caused by the accumulation of melanocytes in the area and is more commonly seen in women of Asian descent. The lesion is usually present at birth or appears in early childhood, but can also develop later in life.
  • Nevus of Ito is a similar condition, but the pigmentation is located on the shoulder and upper arm.
  • Becker's nevus is a hairy patch of skin that appears on the shoulder or upper chest.
  •  Mongolian spot is a common birthmark that appears as a blue-gray patch on the lower back or buttocks.



Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/nevus-of-ota

questions.text: A woman arrived with unilateral leukotrichia and white skin lesions, as shown in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A lady came with unilateral white skin lesions with leukotrichia as shown in the picture. Most likely diagnosis is segmental vitiligo.
  • Segmental Vitiligo:Occurs along a nerve segment
  • Common on face along the branches of trigeminal nerve
  • Stable course, i.e., lesions increase initially (6-12 months) and then remain static.
  • Leukotrichia on the depigmented areas as well as away from vitiliginous areas frequently seen. Margins are feathery.
  • Piebaldism, is a genetic condition that is present from birth and results in a white forelock of hair and depigmented patches on the skin, but it usually affects both sides of the body.
  • Focal vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that affects only a few small areas of the body
  • Waardenburg syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects hearing, pigmentation, and eye color.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text: The glans penis of a 23-year-old male complains of recurrent scaly sores. The same spot would always experience it, and it would recover with a light hyperpigmentation. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Fixed drug eruption
  • Fixed drug eruptions/reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions.
  • They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation.
  • They are usually solitary or few in number and recur at the same location.
  • But, new lesions can occur on different body parts on re-exposure to the offending drug.
  • FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Paracetamol/NSAIDs are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.
  • NSAIDS most commonly cause in lips and Tetracycline and Cotrimazole generally cause in genitals. 
Other options:
  • Herpes simplex infection can cause similar lesions and is a close differential, but it can occur at any site and does not necessarily recur at the same site.
  • Candidal infection - a common cause of balanoposthitis in children may present in association with or secondary to diaper dermatitis
  • Though genital ulcers are seen in Behcet's, the glans penis is not affected by this disease. Even the urethra is spared.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 118.11

questions.text: As seen in the image, a male patient has a hypopigmented patch on his back. What further research would be most beneficial in this situation?
questions.solution:
The image shows a patient suffering from Pityriasis versicolor.
 
Pityriasis Versicolor
  1. Pityriasis Versicolor is a disease caused by Malassezia furfur(a fungus)
  2. It shows hypopigmented, scaly, and perifollicular macules in the upper trunk, neck, and upper arms. Hypopigmentation occurs due to synthesis of azealic acid by fungus which is a tyrosinase inhibitors and reduces formation of melanin. Hyperpigmentation also occurs sometimes due to formation of large melanosomes. 
  3. KOH mount shows Short branched hyphae with spores as spaghetti and meatballs appearance


Hence, KOH mount would be the best investigation among the given options.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.11

questions.text: Which of the following facial congenital lesions is present?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Congenital melanocytic nevus
 
  • The given image showing a black, heterogeneous, hairy palpable lesion in a child is suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus. 
  • Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) are benign, pigmented, melanocytic nevi present at birth.
  • They are most commonly brown, black, purplish, or red, usually a palpable lesion with heterogeneous color and texture.
  • CMN often have thick hair at birth, which grows at a significantly greater rate than the surrounding scalp hair.
  • Melanoacanthoma is a benign skin growth that typically appears as a dark, raised patch on the skin, but it is not typically present at birth.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 75.9

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female patient arrives with a hypopigmented patch and feathery edge on the medial part of her foot. The rest of the physical exam goes as expected.
Which medication from the list below should be avoided when treating this patient?
questions.solution:
• This individual suffers from localized vitiligo. Isotretinoin is used to treat acne, however, because of its teratogenic risk, it should never be administered to a young girl.
  • The remaining alternatives are suitable vitiligo treatment techniques

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman arrives with several linear, scratchy wheals that have been itching for 30 minutes at the spot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Dermographism (or 'skin writing') is a physical urticaria characterised by the appearance of linear wheals that develop after moderate stroking of the skin, or at sites of friction such as collars and cuffs.
  • There are two types of dermographism; Simple immediate dermographism and delayed dermographism, which appears at least 30 minutes after a stroking stimulus.
  • Pressure urticaria is a type of physical urticaria that occurs in response to pressure on the skin, such as from tight clothing or sitting for long periods of time.
  • The wheals are often more diffuse and irregular in shape than those seen in dermatographic urticaria, and may take several hours to develop.
  • Acute urticaria is a type of urticaria that lasts less than six weeks and is often caused by an allergic reaction to a food, medication, or other substance. The wheals are usually round or oval in shape and may be accompanied by other symptoms such as swelling, itching, and difficulty breathing.
  • Chronic urticaria is a type of urticaria that lasts longer than six weeks and may have no identifiable cause. The wheals may be similar in appearance to those seen in acute urticaria, but may also be more persistent and widespread

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 42.8

questions.text: A man arrives with facial rashes and also reports feeling less mentally sharp. On his skin, he also has a few macular lesions. Intracranial calcification was discovered during a CT scan. His spouse is normal. While his 10-year-old daughter seems well, his 6-year-old son similarly exhibits the same skin blemishes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the question posed, the patient has facial angiofibromas as well as an ash leaf macule, mental retardation, seizures, and a positive family history in a child. These features strongly indicate a diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis, which is characterised by autosomal dominant inheritance. Therefore, the answer is option D.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 80.9

questions.text: What is the color of the lesion immediately after photodynamic therapy?
questions.solution:
Option is 1: Unchanged After treating an area with photodynamic therapy, that area of the skin would be usually red, indicating normal erythema, and may appear to be flaking or peeling, as it would after a mild sunburn. Therefore, the color of the lesion would be unchanged or red. The redness, and perhaps some of the flaking, can last for several days to a week or even two weeks. (After that, skin returns to normal.)

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 22.3

questions.text: A 24 years old female presented with complaints of rash on exposure to sun, after exercise, when she gets angry or on eating spicy food. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Itching, burning, tingling, warmth, or irritation precedes the onset of numerous small (1-4 mm in diameter), pruritic wheals with large, surrounding flares is suggestive of Cholinergic urticaria.
  • This condition is caused by an increase in body temperature, which leads to the release of histamine from mast cells in the skin.
  • Exercise is the most common precipitating event for cholinergic urticaria, but any stimulus that causes sweating, including elevated environmental temperature, hot food, sauna baths, immersion in hot water, gustatory stimuli, emotional stress, and hemodialysis, can bring on an urticaria.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 42.11

questions.text: In the image provided, identify the following lesion.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Becker nevus
 
  • Becker nevus is a hyperpigmented hairy patch. 
The shoulder, back, and proximal portion of the upper limb are the most common site involved. Mostly seen in males before puberty. 





Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.62

questions.text: Which of the following is a likely diagnosis based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
• Acute Cutaneous LE refers to any cutaneous (skin) manifestation of lupus that appears suddenly and typically is inflammatory in nature (red, itchy, swollen, etc.).
  • These lesions often appear as patches, plaques, and/or lesions, which can be widespread or localized.
  • Subacute Cutaneous LE refers to a form of cutaneous LE that may appear as red patches, plaques, scaly or ulcerative lesions that can have an inflammatory, noninflammatory, or mixed presentation.
  • Chronic Cutaneous LE refers to a type of Cutaneous LE that has been present for a long period of time and can cause disfigurement of the skin.
  • DLE (Discoid Lupus Erythematosus) is the most common form of cutaneous LE and presents as erythematous to depigmented discoid plaque with adherent scaling usually occurring over face, scalp, neck and 'V' area of chest.
Skin manifestations in SLE


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 51.2

questions.text: Which examination is most effective for allergic contact dermatitis?
questions.solution:
• Patch test is IOC for contact dermatitis.
  • Allergic contact dermatitis occurs when an allergen comes into contact with previously sensitized skin. (Type IV hypersensitivity reaction).

Patch test:
  • The goal of a patch test is to apply suspected dermatitis-causing chemicals to healthy, non-inflamed skin.
  • Test chemicals are applied to the back during TRUE Test (Thin layer Rapid Use Epicutaneous) administration.
  • After 48 hours of application and reading, patches are removed.
  • Sites should be reevaluated after 4-5 days because favorable results might not show up sooner.
  • Below is an image of patch test

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 128.29

questions.text:
The face and neck of a patient from Bihar who had a history of persistent fever as a youngster were affected by nodular, hypopigmented lesions.
Both hypoaesthesia and nerve thickening were absent. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given history (h/o prolonged fever in childhood, living in Bihar) and clinical findings are suggestive of post - Kala Azar dermal leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis is transmitted by sandfly (Phlebotomus Argentipes).

  • PKDL is a complication of Kala Azar following complete/incomplete/irregular treatment of Kala-azar.
  • It presents as macular/papular/nodular skin rash.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 33.50

questions.text: A male patient with a history of feverish joints and back discomfort experiences hyperpigmentation across the nose.  He then takes NSAIDs for relief of pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (4) Chikungunya.
  • Based on the clinical history of fever, joint pain, a rash, and the development of brownish hyperpigmentation over the nose, the most likely diagnosis is pigmentation due to Chikungunya, a condition where the pigmentation of the nose area is quite noticeable.
  • This is also known as thr Chik sign
  • This pigmentation is not usually seen in other viral exanthems.(option 3)
  • In contrast, in the case of a fixed drug eruption, the mucocutaneous junction and genital skin, in particular the glans is most often affected, not the nose. (hence, option (2) is incorrect)
Reference Cutaneous manifestations of chikungunya during a recent epidemic in Calicut, north Kerala, south India, IJDVL 2010. 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.75

questions.text: A young man complained of having strangely shaped lesions all over face. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis in this particular case is Dermatitis artefacta.
  • Dermatitis artefacta or factitious dermatitis is a psychocutaneous disorder 
  • Patients by themselves create lesions on their skin/mucosa/hair or nails to either get attention or evade responsibility or sometimes to satisfy some psychological need. They also hide responsibility for this from their doctors.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.24

questions.text:
A 13-year-old kid presents to the OPD with segmented patches of patchy depigmented skin on the chest and belly.
A year ago, depigmentation began, and during the past few months, there has been no change. Mother recalls using topical steroids in the past, but they weren't very helpful. Which medical diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Clinically speaking, vitiligo is marked by well-defined milky-white macules that may also involve white hairs or poliosis. Vitiligo is an acquired skin disease with progressive melanocyte loss. 
  • The vitiligo segmental variant: One continuous segment is often affected, while two or more segments with ipsilateral or contralateral distribution have been observed. It is distinguished by a unilateral and segmental, or block-shaped, distribution of the lesions. 
  • Little, discrete lesions make focal vitiligo. 
  • Piebaldism: A triangular-shaped white patch on the forehead, sporadic hypopigmented macules, and a congenitally white forelock are involved. 
  • Common areas for involvement include the forehead, chest, abdomen, and extremities. 
  • A well-defined hypopigmented patch called Nerve Depigmentosus is present from birth; it may occasionally become more noticeable in the first year of life as the background skin.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text: Which is the only indication of systemic corticosteroids in psoriasis?
questions.solution:
• One of the indications of systemic corticosteroids in psoriasis is impetigo herpetiformis. Pustular psoriasis in pregnancy is called impetigo herpetiformis.
  • Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare but severe form of psoriasis that typically occurs during pregnancy and is characterized by pustules, erythema, and scaling.
  • Safest drug for treatment of Impetigo herpetiformis is prednisolone as it doesn't cause teratogenicity or any harm to fetus. 
  • Below is an image of impetigo herpetiformis



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.37

questions.text: A man experiences recurring urticaria after being in the sun and exercising. What could be the possible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in this case is cholinergic utricaria.
  • The man experiences recurring urticaria after being in the sun and exercising, which is consistent with the symptoms of cholinergic urticaria.
  • Acetyl choline, which is released by post-ganglionic cholinergic enervated sweat glands in response to any stimulus that causes sweating by raising core body temperature, develops cholinergic urticaria.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 42.11

questions.text: As seen in the picture, a 9-year-old boy has skin blemishes. Lesions have a long history of spontaneously disappearing and reappearing. What is the effective diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pityriasis alba
 
  • The above scenario of a hypopigmented patches is suggestive of pityriasis alba.
  • It is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature. It is seen in the age group of 3-16 years. 
  • Lesions have scaling and are usually not well marginated. In children, the lesions are often confined to the face and are most common on the cheeks and around the mouth and chin.
  • It is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 39.25

questions.text: The following is not associated with acanthosis nigricans:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Addison’s disease

Acanthosis nigricans is associated with Cushing’s syndrome, not Addison’s disease.
  • Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by the symmetrical darkening of the skin of intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck.
  • Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in malignancies, especially those of the gastrointestinal tract, acromegaly, and Cushing's syndrome.
  • Other conditions associated with it include obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, hypothyroidism, obstructive sleep apnea, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. The condition is managed by dietary and lifestyle modifications. Individual components of the syndrome also need to be addressed by the use of statins, antihypertensives, or hypoglycemic agents.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 87.2

questions.text: An obese lady presented to the Skin OPD with the complaints of dark patches over neck as shown in the figure. It is associated with:
questions.solution:
The given clinical image demonstrates hyperpigmented velvety lesions in the skin flexure at the back of neck, known as acanthosis nigricans. 

It is commonly associated with metabolic syndrome. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 390, 2933, 2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3154-3156.

questions.text: A hypopigmented patch which grows initially and stops progressing after sometime is seen in which type of vitiligo?
questions.solution:
• In segmental vitiligo, lesions increase initially (6-12 months) and then remain static.
  • Here the lesions appear only on one side of the body in a limited area- Appears as unilateral macule in a segmented or band shaped pattern.
  • It's less common than non-segmental vitiligo, but it's more common in children, affecting around 3 in 10 children with vitiligo.
  • Acrofacial vitiligo - Generalised Vitiligo predominantly seen periorificially and acral parts.More resisitant to therapy
  • Mixed Vitiligo- Coexistence of non-segmental and segmental vitiligo in same patient.
Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 88.34-88.40.

choices.text: The skin lesions exacerbate on sun exposure

questions.text: A 40 year old female presented with the following skin lesions. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
The following image shows skin lesions suggestive of melasma.
Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females. Melasma presents as hypermelanosis of the upper lip, malar regions, forehead, and chin. There may also be darkening of the nipples, linea alba, and groin. The lesions are usually bilateral and symmetrical. Treatment includes Sun protection, changing oral contraceptives to low estrogen formulation, or triple therapy with topical hydroquinone, tretinoin, and corticosteroid cream. In resistant cases chemical peels or laser therapy can be tried .
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition • Page 88.10 - 88.12

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a type of lichen planus.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Lichen scrofulous
  • Lichen scrofulosorum also known as “tuberculosis cutis lichenoides,” is a rare tuberculid that presents as a lichenoid eruption of minute papules in children and adolescents with tuberculosis.
  • The lesions are usually asymptomatic, closely grouped, skin-colored to reddish-brown papules, often perifollicular, and are mainly found on the abdomen, chest, back, and proximal parts of the limbs.
  • The eruption is usually associated with a strongly positive tuberculin reaction.
There are many variants of lichen planus based on morphology and location.
They are:
  • Oral, nail,
  • Linear, annular
  • Atrophic, hypertrophic
  • Inverse, eruptive, bullous, ulcerative
  • Lichen planus pigmentosus
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Vulvovaginal, actinic
  • Lichen planus-lupus erythematosus overlap syndrome
  • Lichen planus pemphigoides
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 27.26

questions.text: As seen in the illustration below, an 11-year-old boy had plaques in his cubital and popliteal fossa that were itchy and hyperpigmented. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Atopic dermatitis
 
  • The given clinical history of plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.
  • Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema.
  • The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).
  • The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years.
  • There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. 
  • Below are the differences between Atopic dermatitis and Psoriasis.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 41.1

questions.text: 34y old patient comes to your OPD with the following complaint of having severe acne causing discomfort. Below is an image of the patient. What would be the best line of management?
questions.solution:
• In the given image, the patient is suffering from severe nodulocystic acne with pus filled lesions.
  • Oral therapy with Isotretinoin is indicated in such a patient.
  • High dose anti-androgens can be given to females in reproductive age group as alternative therapy.
Below is a treatment approach in patients with Acne

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.39

questions.text: A 18-year-old boy came with a progressively worsening annular plaque which has central scarring on his head and neck region. Which diagnosis is most likely amongst these?
questions.solution:
• In Lupus vulgaris, an annular plaque with a central scar is characteristic.
  • Central scarring is never seen in the annular plaque-like Tinea cruris lesions, despite the fact that Tinea cruris is significantly more prevalent.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 27.21

questions.text: A 19-year-old man has multiple comedones, papules, and pustules on his face and body. Which medicine would be the best option for the patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is s/o grade 3 acne which requires treatment with oral antibiotics along with topical retinoids.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.39

questions.text: A young 8-year-old kid exhibits numerous distinct, shiny, pin-head-sized papules on the dorsal part of his hands, forearms, and penis shaft. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Lichen nitidus (LN) is an uncommon chronic skin eruption characterised by multiple, tiny, discrete, skin-colored papules with a shiny surface, often arranged in large clusters.
  • It is typically found on the flexor aspects of the upper extremities, genitalia, chest and abdomen of children or young adults.
  • Upto 10% of patients may have nail involvement with changes including pitting, longitudinal ridging, and terminal splitting.
  • The Koebner phenomenon may also be present. Pruritus is an uncommon feature. Scabies on the other hand, presents with burrows in the skin folds and flexor aspects.





Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text:
A patient had onycholysis, thinned nails, and flat-topped violaceous papules.
What microscopic phenomenon was seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is of Lichen Planus. 
  • Autoimmune disorder
  • T cell mediated response
  • Antigen is not known. Caused by known drugs and dental Amalgams
  • Clinical Features -5P's : Purple, Plane topped, pruritic, Papules, Polygonal.
  • Characterstics- Involves skin mucosa and nails
  • Koebner -Positive
  • Wickhams striae - Reticular whitish lines that are seen on a plaque of lichen planus due to hypergranulosis.
  • HPE- Hyperkeratosis, Hypergranulosis, Basal cell Degeneration, Colloid/civet bodies, Saw tooth rete ridges and Max Joseph Space {between infiltrate and epidermis}


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.12

questions.text: All of the following drugs can lead to SLE like reaction except?
questions.solution:
• Drugs causing SLE can be remembered by the mnemonic-SHIP
  • S-Sulphonamides H-Hydralazine I-Isoniazid P-Procainamide 
  • They are associated with anti-histone antibodies with equal incidence in males and females and absent renal involvement.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 51.19

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for erythrodermic psoriasis?
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate is the drug of choice for management of Erythrodermic Psoriasis.
  • Cyclosporine is also used for fast remission and later for maintenance methotrexate is used. 
  • Topical applications are adequate only for Psoriasis Vulgaris, not for the systemic variants.
  • The only indication of Oral steroids in Psoriasis is Pustular psoriasis of pregnancy.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.26

questions.text: A 45 years old male presents with itchy papules over face, neck and V area of chest for the last three years, which are exacerbated in summers and improved in winters. What test will you do to confirm diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 1: Patch test The given history points towards photoallergic contact dermatitis and is a delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • The dermatitis is localized to exposed areas of the skin, usually with welldemarcated margins where the skin is covered by clothing, for example at the collar and ‘V’ of the neck, below the end of sleeves on the backs of the hands, and on the ankles below the trouser legs.
  • Photopatch test: The main clinical indication includes the investigation of patients with eczematous rashes predominantly affecting lightexposed sites and a history of worsening following sun exposure.
Below is an image of Patch Test


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 39.5

questions.text: The image depicts a child who has a rash. His family has a history of asthma. What is the most likely medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Atopic dermatitis
 
  • Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema.
  • In infants, it presents as erythema and edematous papule in the face and extensor aspect of the knees and elbows. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).
  • The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years.
  • There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. 
Other features of atopic dermatitis include xerosis (dry skin), ichthyosis (fish-like scaly skin), and headlight sign (facial eczema sparing periorbital, perinasal, and perioral area).



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 41.16

questions.text: When a pregnant woman has an erythematous skin rash with several pus lakes, she should take:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Corticosteroids
 
  • Impetigo herpetiformis (pustular psoriasis of pregnancy) is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids.
  • Steroids can also be used for the control of acute symptoms like ARDS accompanying pustular psoriasis.
  • Steroids are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis as sudden withdrawal can trigger severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis. 
  • As most of the other medications are contraindicated in pregnancy, this is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 115.8

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis in the case of a psoriatic patient who showed good response to oral steroids but on stopping of these drugs he developed the lesions?
questions.solution:
The image shows pustular psoriasis.

Pustular psoriasis may be precipitated by :

1. Rapid tapering of corticosteroids (or other systemic therapies) / Sudden corticosteroid withdrawal
2. Pregnancy,
3. Hypocalcemia
4. Infections
5. Topical Irritants

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.32

questions.text: Which among the following conditions does not manifest as maculopapular rash
questions.solution:
• Maculopapular rash is absent in zoster (singles).
  • Instead it produces blister, scab, ulcer or redness.
  • The following diseases can cause maculopapular rashes: Dengue (Febrile phase), Rubella, measles, acute retroviral syndrome, chikungunya (acute infectious phase), infectious mononucleosis, West Nile virus, and erythema infectiosum.



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition |I Page no 4.13

questions.text: 30y old male came to your OPD with the following  lesion. What is the best description for the given lesion?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an annular lesion.

Annular lesion:
  • Circular lesion with central clearing.
  • Infectious Causes:
    • Dermatophyte
    • Impetigo
    • Syphilis
    • Leprosy
  • May be inflammatory
  • May occur due to psoriasis

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 4.9

questions.text: A young woman complained of having strangely shaped lesions all over her face and arms, as seen in the picture. What is the most likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Dermatitis artefacta
 
  • Symmetrical distribution of lesions on face and arms in easy to reach areas.
  • Moreover, the lesions seem to be in varying stages of healing, like as in an abrasion.
  • This is a psychocutaneus condition
  • This points out to the diagnosis of dermatitis artefacta
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.24

questions.text:
Eczematous dermatitis covering the extensor surfaces is seen in a 3-year-old child.
Bronchial asthma had already affected his mother.
What should be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most probable diagnosis in a 3-year old child, who presents with eczematous dermatitis over the extensor surfaces with family history of bronchial asthma is atopic dermatitis.
  • AD is a cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, hay fever or dermatitis.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 41.16

questions.text: What is the term for tiny bleeding areas in plaque psoriasis following the removal of deep scales?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Auspitz sign

Bleeding points post removal of deep scales indicate Auspitz's sign is characteristic of psoriasis.  It occurs due to suprapapillary thinning and increased vasculature to Rete ridges. 

Psoriasis:
  • Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. 
  • Plaque psoriasis is the most common type.
  • The nails are frequently involved, and pitting is the most common finding seen. Nail beds can also be affected, giving rise to the oil-drop sign—a highly specific sign seen in this condition.
  • Other manifestations include subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.



Nail changes seen in lichen planus and psoriasis:




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.10

questions.text: Where is the "Carpet Tack" sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: DLE
 
  • Carpet tack sign or tin- tack sign, or cat's tongue sign, is seen in DLE. It means hyperkeratosis and plugging of the follicular ostia with keratotic material.
  • In cutaneous lupus erythematosus or discoid lupus erythematosus, the skin lesions present as well-defined erythematous patches with adherent scaling and peripheral hyperpigmentation. 
  • When the scale is removed its undersurface shows horny plugs that have occupied dilated pilosebaceous canals. This is called the ‘tintack’ sign.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 51.4

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on his shins for the past 3 months. The patient also gives a history of chewing tobacco for 20 years. She occasionally drinks alcohol and smokes. On examination, the lesions are seen as in the image below. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with pruritic, purple, flat-topped papules on the shins, which are classic features of lichen planus. Contributing factors include tobacco use and alcohol, which may exacerbate oral lesions.

Management:

  • First-line treatment: Topical corticosteroids

    • Reduce inflammation and pruritus

    • Usually applied under occlusion for better efficacy

  • Systemic therapy (methotrexate, oral corticosteroids, cyclosporin):

    • Reserved for severe, widespread, or refractory cases

    • Not first-line due to potential systemic side effects

Other supportive measures:

  • Avoid triggers (tobacco, alcohol, certain medications)

  • Emollients for symptomatic relief

questions.text: Which of the following is seen on the microscopy in patients with lichen planus?
questions.solution:
• Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting skin and mucous membranes.

  • Histopathology features:

    • Colloid bodies (Civatte bodies): Eosinophilic, hyaline, apoptotic keratinocytes in the basal layer or papillary dermis, hallmark of lichen planus

    • Saw-tooth appearance of rete ridges

    • Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction

  • Other options:

    • Pautrier's microabscess: Seen in mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma)

    • Munro microabscess: Seen in psoriasis (collections of neutrophils in stratum corneum)

    • Michaelis–Gutmann bodies: Seen in malakoplakia (intracellular inclusions in histiocytes)

questions.text: A 5-day-old infant is seen with a rash on his nose, cheek and forehead, as shown in the image below. On examination, they are noted to be pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is milia. This condition is characterized by small cysts that form around the pilosebaceous follicles, typically appearing on the nose, cheeks, and forehead. These cysts are pearly, opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts.

In some cases, infantile milia may be associated with oral lesions on the gingivae or palate. While milia are more prevalent in white children, they are less common in those born prematurely or of low gestational weight. Fortunately, milia usually resolve on their own without leaving any scars.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are known to cause wheals?
questions.solution:
• Urticaria is a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by itchy wheals, which develop due to evanescent edema of dermis.
  • A wheal is a transient, well-demarcated, superficial pink or pale swellings of the dermis due to reversible exudation of plasma in the skin that fade, usually within hours, without leaving a mark.
  • Wheals are usually very itchy and associated with a surrounding red flare when they arise.
Porokeratosis, Tinea corporis and Pityriasis rosea are known to cause annular lesions.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 65.67.

questions.text: A 24 year old young male presented with asymptomatic scaly lesions over back, symmetrical in distribution. Images of the lesions are given, Identify the disease and the pattern of lesions
questions.solution:
The description provided, which includes central detachment and peripheral attachment of scales with images suggestive of collarette scales and a Christmas tree pattern, indicates pityriasisrosea. This condition, also known as pityriasiscircinata or roseolaannulata, is an acute, self-limiting papulosquamous disorder frequently observed in children and young adults.

Clinical features of pityriasisrosea include:

A prodrome characterized by sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbances, fever, or arthralgia.

Herald patch: A large, prominent lesion typically found on the thigh, upper arm, trunk, or neck, covered by fine scales.


Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 115.9,35.8,37.3 .

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient comes with the following findings. Which of the following is pathognomic of the primary stage of this disease?
questions.solution:
Comedones are characteristic of the primary stage of acne.

Acne is a polymorphic inflammatory condition affecting the pilosebaceous unit, commonly found on the face, back, and chest. Comedonal lesions are the earliest manifestations of acne, representing keratin plugs within the pilosebaceous duct. When the keratin plug remains within the follicle, it is referred to as a closed comedone (or Whitehead). Conversely, when the keratin plug is exposed to the air, it oxidizes and becomes black, known as an open comedone (or blackhead).

Precipitating factors for acne include:

Lifestyle and environmental influences, such as diet, body mass index (BMI), smoking and alcohol consumption, menstrual cycles, stress, and lack of sleep.
Medications, including corticosteroids and anticonvulsants.
Assessment of acne involves:

Leed's photometric grading scale
Comprehensive Acne Severity System (CASS)
Management of acne is categorized as follows:

1. Mild acne:

Comedonal acne: topical retinoid
Papular and pustular acne: topical retinoid combined with topical antibiotics
2. Moderate papular or pustular acne and nodular acne: oral antibiotics, topical retinoid, and benzoyl peroxide

3. Severe nodular and conglobate acne: oral isotretinoin

4. Other therapies may include topical niacinamide, salicylic acid, chemical peels, lasers, and photodynamic therapy.

Novel drugs targeting both retinoic acid receptors - beta and gamma include:

Adapalene
Tazarotene
Tretinoin
Additionally, a topical androgen receptor inhibitor, 1% clascoterone cream, is available.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces of both arms. Punctate pitting was noted on examining the nails. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of erythematous plaques with silvery scales on the extensor surfaces of the arms, along with punctate pitting of the nails, strongly indicates psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that may have systemic implications. The most common form is plaque psoriasis.

The peak onset typically occurs between 16 to 22 years and again between 57 to 62 years. Patients often report itching and present with a papulosquamous rash.
The lesions are characterized by their red and scaly appearance, with well-defined borders from surrounding normal skin.
Sometimes, they are surrounded by a clear peripheral area known as the Woronoff ring.
Common locations for the lesions include the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.
The Koebner phenomenon (or isomorphic phenomenon) describes the formation of new lesions at sites of trauma, resulting in linear lesions.
Nail changes are frequently observed in all types of psoriasis. Patients may exhibit pits, ridges, and grooves on the nail plates. If the nail bed is affected, signs such as subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis may occur.



The histopathological hallmark of psoriasis includes multiple neutrophilic foci in the parakeratotic stratum corneum (referred to as Munro's microabscesses) and spongiform neutrophils in the spinous layer of the epidermis (known as spongiform pustules of Kogoj).

Management primarily involves the topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients. Other treatment options may include phototherapy, along with systemic medications such as oral methotrexate, acitretin, and cyclosporine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient, who is a known case of ovarian cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

The image provided depicts lilac erythema or heliotrope rash on the upper eyelids, which is a hallmark sign of dermatomyositis. The clinical features include proximal myopathy accompanied by a rash in an elderly female patient with a history of internal malignancy, further supporting the diagnosis of dermatomyositis.


Other notable cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis include:

Heliotrope rash/eyelid erythema: Violaceous erythema affecting the upper eyelids.
V sign: Confluent macular erythema across the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest.
Shawl sign: Confluent macular erythema on the upper back and the lateral aspects of the arms.
Gottron's papules: Erythematous papules and plaques located on the extensor surfaces of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints.
Gottron's sign: Erythematous rash on the extensor surfaces of joints, such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles.
Mechanic's hands: Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmar surfaces of the fingers.

questions.text: A patient presented with itchy lesions as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image displaying pruritic, purple, polygonal papules is characteristic of lichen planus.

Lichen planus is classified as a lichenoid disorder that primarily affects the papillary dermis. It is an autoimmune disease mediated by T-cells targeting basal keratinocytes and is recognized for its chronic nature, often experiencing multiple relapses and remissions.

Several factors can trigger the onset of lichen planus, including:

Viruses: Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpes viruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), and Varicella zoster.
Genetic predisposition: Associations with HLA-A3 and HLA-5.
Environmental factors:
Medications such as antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, and anticonvulsants.
Radiotherapy.
Psychological factors like anxiety, depression, and stress.
The most common manifestation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This presentation is summarized by the characteristic "6 P's" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

questions.text: Which type of psoriasis is more common in children?
questions.solution:
Guttate psoriasis is a distinct variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults.
On examination, guttate psoriasis manifests as numerous, small scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as "drop-like" and typically manifest as round or slightly oval 2 to 10 mm papules. Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Vol II page 35.4

questions.text: A 24 year old female presented with the following skin lesions over the face. Identify the condition
questions.solution: Comedonal lesions are the earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct and are non-inflammatory. When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone/whitehead. Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume III • Chapter 90 Page nos 90.21 and 90.22

questions.text: Which of the following features are not associated with the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis: Lichen Planus
Munro’s microabscesses are not seen in lichen planus—they are characteristic of psoriasis.

Histopathological Features of Lichen Planus (H&E stain):

  1. Hypergranulosis – thickened granular layer

  2. Acanthosis – due to thickening of the stratum spinosum

  3. Max-Joseph spaces – small areas of basal cell degeneration and clefting

  4. Civatte bodies (Colloid bodies) – eosinophilic, apoptotic keratinocytes in the basal layer

  5. Hyperkeratosis – thickening of the stratum corneum

  6. Orthokeratosis – presence of anucleate keratin in the stratum corneum

  7. Pigment incontinence – melanin within dermal macrophages due to basal cell damage

  8. Saw-tooth appearance – irregular acanthosis of rete ridges

    Clinical Features (The 6 Ps):

  • Planar (flat-topped)

  • Purple

  • Polygonal

  • Pruritic

  • Papules

  • Involving flexor surfaces

  • Wickham’s striae – fine white reticulated lines on mucosal lesions

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no 37.3,37.12,37.14,32.36,32.38,34.40,34.43,35.7,35.8
8

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image below and later developed arthritis also. What is the treatment of choice for a patient who presented with the following findings?
questions.solution:
In this case, 

  • Right knee effusion

  • Dactylitis (sausage-like swelling of fingers/toes)

  • Sharply demarcated, red papulosquamous lesions over the knees

    Typical Features of PsA:

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis (especially lower limb joints)

  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement

  • Enthesitis (inflammation at tendon/ligament insertions)

  • Nail changes: pitting, onycholysis

  • Dactylitis: hallmark feature

    Radiologic Findings:

  • “Pencil-in-cup” deformity at DIP joints

  • Marginal erosions with periosteal new bone formation ("whiskering")

  • Ankylosis of small joints in severe cases

  • Ray pattern involvement (affecting all joints of a single digit)

    First-Line Treatment Options:

  • Methotrexate

    • Disease-modifying agent for moderate to severe PsA

    • Controls both articular and cutaneous manifestations

  • Apremilast

    • Oral phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor

    • Effective for both psoriasis and PsA, especially in cases where methotrexate is contraindicated or not tolerated


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 2571-2572

questions.text: A child was brought in with lesions over the elbows and penis shaft that were similar to those in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Grouped pin/read lesions on elbow, abdomen, penis and dorsum of hand in a child as shown in the picture is highly suggestive of lichen nitidus.
  • Lichen nitidus appears as small, shiny, flat-topped bumps that are skin-colored, yellow, red-brown, or violet. They can be 1–3 mm in diameter and are often round or polygonal in shape.
  • It  can be localized or generalized, and  can cluster together to form plaques.
 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man from Bihar arrives with papules  which are hypopigmented and normal sensation over his face and the back of his neck.
A prolonged fever episode in childhood was documented while taking  history. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is based on:
  • History of kala-azar in the past (1-5 years ago) or living in endemic area.
  • Presence of "juicy'' erythematous nodules on the central part of the face.
  • Hypopigmented macules on the central part of the trunk.
  • No nerve involvement
  • PKDL can appear weeks, months, or even years after successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, often occurring in endemic regions.
  • Diagnosis is typically made based on clinical examination and history of previous leishmaniasis infection, with possible confirmation through skin biopsies or serological test

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 33.50

questions.text: The following lesions are present across the body, primarily on the trunk, in a 7-month-old  pregnant woman. Which of these medications is most suitable for the treatment?
questions.solution:
• The image given is of Pustular Psoriasis of Pregnancy.
  • Usually seen in third trimester
  • Recur in subsequent pregnancy
  • Presents with scaling on trunk/abdomen/legs.
  • DOC- Oral steroids ( only type of psoriasis where oral steroids are used)


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 35.28

questions.text:
A man with leprosy arrived with the shin lesion shown in the image below.
Which spectrum of Leprosy does this patient fall under?
questions.solution:
• Inverted saucer-shaped lesions are characteristic features of borderline Borderline (BB) leprosy.



 




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10

questions.text: A 24-year-old male laments having pimples. Multiple nodules, cysts, and  sinuses were discovered during an examination. What will you do concerning his treatment?
questions.solution:
• The patient is suffering from Severe Acne based on nodulocystic appearance and hence requires Oral Isotretinoin for treatment.
  • Tazarotene is a topical retinoid while acitretin is used in the treatment of psoriasis. 



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37

choices.text: Rifampicin (450 mg) + Dapsone (50 mg) + Clofazimine (150 mg) monthly
{Rifampicin (450 mg) + Dapsone (50 mg) + Clofazimine (150 mg)} monthly and 50 mg/alt day and 50 mg dapsone daily
{Rifampicin (600 mg) + Dapsone (100 mg) + Clofazimine (300 mg)} monthly and 50 mg/daily and dapsone 100mg daily.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child complained of four hypopigmented areas on his left arm and back. Sensation was lost in the spots. Which of the following describes how this case should be treated?
Which of the following describes how this case should be treated?
questions.solution:
