Correct option is 3: {Rifampicin (450 mg) + Clofazimine (150 mg)} monthly and 50 mg/alt day and 50 mg dapsone daily
  • The clinical scenario of hypopigmented skin lesions and damaged nerves, indicated by absence of sensation suggests paucibacillary leprosy.
  • The treatment of paucibacillary leprosy (PB) is multidrug therapy (MDT) with rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine 
  • The dosage depends on the age of the patient, as advised by WHO.
  • In a child aged between 10 and 14 years, the treatment is {Rifampicin (450 mg) + Clofazimine (150 mg)} monthly and 50 mg/alt day and 50 mg dapsone daily



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.2,

questions.text: Using histopathology, determine the disease as displayed in the figure:
questions.solution:
The biopsy reveals a suprabasal split, the basal epidermis has a row-of-tombstones, and acantholytic cells are seen within the split. These findings are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.
 
  • A basal split caused by necrotic basal keratinocytes is seen in TEN.
  • Mycosis fungoides and lepromatous leprosy have an almost normal epidermis without any splits.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2, 50.4, 50.7

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman has had two months with asymptomatic dome-shaped tiny lesions on her forehead. She has a daughter, age 2, who has comparable lesions.
What is the cause of the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The lesions in the given picture on the forehead are pearly white papules and with a history of transmission to her daughter, the most likely diagnosis is Molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by the poxvirus.
  • In molluscum contagiosum, typical lesions which are pink or skin coloured in the form of an umbilicated papule containing a greyish central plug. It is seen commonly in children.
  • The face and genitals are commonly involved and the face is most commonly involved in children, in whom the groin and genitals are not affected, which are usually involved in sexually active adults.

 
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.13

questions.text: What is your diagnosis for a young patient who presents to the OPD with a history of black central arch rashes on his body?
questions.solution:
• The image shows characteristic meningococcal rashes having black central arch and surrounding ring or erythema.
  • Non blanching rashes develop in more than 80% of meningococcal diseases.
  • The causative organism is Neisseria meningitidis.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 26.49

questions.text: For one month, a young male has had the following itchy lesion: Which of the following genera cannot cause this kind of lesion?
questions.solution:
• The above lesions are suggestive of Tinea cruris, also known as crotch itch which is a dermatophyte fungal infection of the groin region.
  • Causes: usually Trichophyton rubrum
Dermatophytes
  •      Microsporum
  •     Epidermophyton
  •      Trichophyton.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.46

questions.text:
As shown in the picture, a young boy with greasy skin exhibits acne.
What is the proper course of treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
• The diagram shows severe nodulocystic acne with pus filled lesions.
  • Oral therapy with Isotretinoin is indicated is such a patient.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman has had asymptomatic dome-shaped, tiny lesions on her forehead for two months. Her 2-year-old daughter suffers from comparable lesions.
Which is the lesion's causative agent?
questions.solution:
• The pearly white papule lesions on the forehead are most likely Molluscum contagiosum, which is brought on by the poxvirus and has a history of being passed down to daughters:
  • Molluscum contagiosum (MC), often known as water warts, is a viral infection of the skin or mucous membranes that is brought on by the molluscum virus, a DNA poxvirus (MCV)
  • The lesions of molluscum contagiosum have a flesh-colored, dome-shaped, and pearly look. 
  • They are often 1-5 mm in diameter, with an umbilicated center.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.12, 25.13

questions.text:
A young man with an anesthetic patch on his right forearm arrived.
On examination, a thicker nerve was palpable.
This image comes from a skin biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient has presented with a single anesthetic patch and single enlarged nerve, and a well defined granuloma can be seen on the skin biopsy.
  • These findings are typical of Tuberculoid Leprosy.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.7, 28.8

questions.text:
One month after commencing anti-epileptic medication, a 28-year-old patient with neurocysticercosis begins to have universal peeling of all skin surfaces apart from the palms and soles.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical description provided above is typical of toxic epidermal necrolysis and includes a history of drug use (anticonvulsant) followed by confluent skin involvement (likely to be greater than 30%).
  • Lyell's syndrome, commonly known as toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), is a rare, potentially fatal skin disorder that is typically brought on by a medication reaction. The condition leads to a separation between the upper epidermis and the lower dermis of the skin.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.13

questions.text: Which of the following types of oral candidiasis does not have a white patch?
questions.solution:
Chronic Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion instead of a white patch seen in all other types.

Types of Oral Candidiasis
  Pseudomembranous:
Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis is a classic form of oral candidiasis, commonly referred to as thrush.
 Characterized by a coating or individual patches of the pseudomembranous white slough that can be easily wiped away to reveal erythematous, and sometimes minimally bleeding mucosa beneath.
Erythematous:
Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis is where the condition appears as a red, raw-looking lesion.
Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis:
Chronic candidal lesions on the skin, in the mouth, and on other mucous membranes (i.e. secondary oral candidiasis).
Hyperplastic:
This variant is also sometimes termed 'plaque-like candidiasis' or 'nodular candidiasis' or 'candidal leukoplakia'.
The most common appearance of hyperplastic candidiasis is a persistent white plaque that does not rub off.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.62

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man came in with itchiness on his fingertips.
Below is a clinical description of the lesion and its etiological agent. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The history of itching across the fingers and the presence of lesions in the finger webs as seen in the picture strongly suggest scabies.
  • Scabies is characterized by intractable itchiness, which is typically worse at night.
  • The lesions first develop on the web gaps, then spread to the sides of the fingers, the flexor surfaces of the wrists and elbows, and the anterior axillary folds.
  • The areolae in women, the buttocks, the sacrum and periumbilical regions, as well as the penis and scrotum, are other common locations for lesions.
  • Eczematous and frequently excoriated lesions are possible, but the burrow—a brief, wavy, dark line—is the hallmark lesion.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 34.41, 34.40

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given picture is of hand-foot-mouth disease caused by Coxsackie virus.
  • Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD): After an incubation period of 4-6 days, patients with HFMD present with fever, anorexia, and malaise; these manifestations are followed by the development of sore throat and vesicles on the buccal mucosa and frequently on the tongue; these lesions are then followed by the appearance of tender vesicular lesions on the dorsum of the hands, occasionally involving the palms.
  • The vesicles may become bullae and ulcerate very soon.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 117.6,117.7

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man had multiple small hypopigmented patches around his hair follicles on his upper chest and back. Macules had fine scaling that coalesced later.
Before one year, the patient received treatment, and it was successful. Which of the following tests would be most useful??
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis versicolor is a common fungal infection caused by the yeast species Malassezia furfur.
  • It presents as multiple, small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back which are circular, arranged around follicles and can coalesce to form large sheets with fine scaling.
  • The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation.
  • A KOH preparation can be done with a scraping of the affected area, which will show the characteristic short branching adapted yeasts.
  • The fungus can also be seen under the microscope with other staining techniques such as periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) and Giemsa.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.11, 32.12

questions.text: A patient has multiple hyperesthetic and hypopigmented patches on the lateral aspect of the forearm with abundant acid-fast bacteria and granulomatous inflammation is seen. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Borderline lepromatous leprosy is a form of leprosy which is characterized by multiple hypoaesthetic and hypopigmented macules on the skin. 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.8

questions.text: Mid borderline leprosy is characterised by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Borderline(BB) leprosy is characterized by hypopigmented macules or plaques with Annular Swiss cheese/inverted saucer appearance.
  • The lesions are usually variable in number ~ 10-30. 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10

questions.text: A young 8 years old boy with multiple, small, pin point, shiny, papular lesions on dorsal aspect of hand, forearms and his penis also. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Lichen nitidus is a rare skin disorder that is characterized by small, pinhead-sized, shiny, flat-topped papules.
  • These papules often form clusters, which can range in size from a few millimeters to up to a centimeter. They usually appear on the trunk, upper arms, neck, and face, and may be more common in children and adolescents.
  • The color of the papules can vary from yellow-brown, to pink or white. Lichen nitidus is asymptomatic and does not cause itching or irritation.
  • The diagnosis of Lichen nitidus is based on the appearance of the papules. A skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.
  • Treatment is usually not necessary, although topical steroids may be used to reduce any inflammation. Long-term prognosis for Lichen nitidus is excellent, as it is considered a harmless condition.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with painful boggy swelling of the scalp, multiple discharging sinuses, easily pluckable hairs, and lymph nodes enlarged in the occipital region. Which one of the following would be most helpful for diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
• The given features (painful boggy swelling of the scalp, multiple discharging sinuses, easily pluckable hairs) are consistent with that of Kerion or Tinea Capitis.
  • Tinea capitis(scalp ringworm) is a fungal infection of the scalp and hair. It appears as patches of scaling, broken hair, and inflammation or bald spots on the scalp.
  • The most common symptom is itching, but the affected area may also be tender. The diagnosis of tinea capitis is usually based on a physical inspection of the infected area.
  • Confirmation can be achieved using laboratory testing, such as fungal culture on KOH wet mount, direct tissue examination, and Wood's lamp examination.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.39

questions.text: The Ridley-Joplin classification for leprosy is based on which parameters?
questions.solution:
The Ridley-Jopling classification for leprosy is a system designed in 1967 to classify the type of leprosy a person is affected with. The classification takes into account the degree to which patients have been affected by the disease by Clinical, bacteriological and immunological parameters and assigns them one of five stages of severity: 1. Tuberculoid Leprosy: This is the least severe type of leprosy. It affects few areas of skin or nerves, and in some cases can remain stable after treatment. 2. Mid-Range Leprosy: Symptoms may include discolored skin patches, known as macules, and some nerve damage. 3. Borderline Leprosy: Symptoms may include uneven skin patches, patches with several colors, and greater nerve damage, but still no physical deformities. 4. Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy: Symptoms may include large patches with multiple colors, significant nerve damage and physical deformities, such as clubbed fingers. 5. Lepromatous Leprosy: This is the most severe type of leprosy. Symptoms include widespread skin lesions, gross deformities, and general deterioration of health. The Ridley-Jopling classification is based on the appearances of skin lesions, deformities, as well as the degree of body reactions to antigenic and bacterial tests.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.3,28.12

questions.text:
An industrial worker presents to you with groin plaques that are scaly, annular, and irritating. The pruritus is reduced after applying corticosteroid ointment, however, the lesion's peripheral extension persisted and worsens.
What is the plausible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• The above lesions/history is suggestive of Tinea cruris(crotch itch) which is a dermatophyte fungal infection of the groin region.
  • Caused usually by Trichophyton rubrum. The clinical picture includes Itching or a burning sensation in the groin area, thigh skin folds or anus, and scaly/annular lesions.
  • Steroids being anti-inflammatory initially decrease the acute inflammation and hence the pruritis/itching but they can also make antifungal medications less effective and the primary infection worse. (Reason why peripheral extension persisted and then worsened)




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.46, 32.47

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented with multiple hypoaesthetic patches over trunk and extremities. On examination, ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves are enlarged bilaterally. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient here has multiple hypo-esthetic patches (seen in border­line leprosy) and bilateral symmetrical nerve thickening (suggestive of Lepromatous leprosy).
  • Now in lepromatous leprosy(LL), there is normal anesthesia. Hence, the patient fits in the category of Borderline Lepro­matous Leprosy(BL).





Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.8

questions.text: An apparently healthy male appears with a white area on his tongue that looks like creamy curd. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Candidiasis
 
  • The given clinical scenario of white curdy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient is oral candidiasis. The drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.
  • Candida albicans is an opportunistic pathogen that causes candidiasis. It is yeast when part of the normal flora of mucous membranes but forms pseudo-hyphae and hyphae when it invades tissue.
  • They are not dimorphic. It forms germ tubes when incubated at 37 degrees Celsius. It is gram-positive and forms colonies of yeasts on Sabouraud's agar.
  • Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis: Sharply defined patch of creamy, crumbly, curdlike, white pseudomembrane



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.59,32.56

questions.text:
The patient, a 42-year-old man, had lesions as depicted below.
Which of these is the best course of action for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Leonines facies (thickened nodular lesions on foreheard, ears, eyebrows, and cheeks) seen in and classically described for Lepromatous leprosy.
  • Hence, the patient should be started on MDT for leprosy.
  • In Lepromatous leprosy, the skin and soft tissues of the face can thicken, leading to a lion-like appearance, which is where the term "leonine" comes from.
  • This change is due to the effects of the disease on the skin and underlying tissues, including loss of eyebrows and changes in the nose's structure.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.9

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD with the following lesion which was associated with itching. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a fungal skin infection typically caused by a type of fungus known as dermatophytes.
  • It typically presents as an itchy, annular (ring-shaped) plaque with well-defined borders, peripheral papulopustular, scaling, and central clearing.
  • The most common organism responsible for this infection is a type of dermatophyte named Trichophyton rubrum.
Trick: -
Annular lesion with central clearing- Tinea
Annular lesion with central scarring- Lupus vulgaris
Annular lesion with central crusting- Cutaneous leishmaniasis 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.35, 32.36, 31.26

questions.text: A young patient comes to your OPD with the following lesions over the lips. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis of herpes labialis is primarily made by visual inspection of the affected area.
  • The most typical presentation is a cluster of small, round, painful vesicles or blisters on a reddened base, often accompanied by painful sores on or near the lips or near the nose.
  • However, diagnosis of herpes labialis can be confirmed more definitively by laboratory tests such as the PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test, the Tzanck test, or a viral culture of lesions.
  • PCR testing is the most accurate, and it can detect the virus even in people who do not have obvious symptoms.
  • The given image shows blisters which indicate herpes labialis but in impetigo yellowish brown crusts would be seen


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.18

questions.text: A farmer appeared with the following symptoms: swelling on the foot and discharge from the sinuses. What  is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis, based on the information provided in the inquiry and the photograph, which depicts many discharging sinuses, is mycetoma.
  • Mycetoma : Chronic granulomatous subcutaneous inflammatory disease caused by filamentous bacteria ( actinomycetoma ) or true fungi ( eumycetoma ).
  • Triad of Progressive subcutaneous swelling with sinus tracts that discharge grains is seen in cases of mycetoma.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.74,32.75

questions.text: A young child appears with the asymptomatic lesions depicted below on the dorsum of the hand and penile shaft. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (4) Lichen Nitidus.

  • The given image shows a lesion suggestive of Lichen nitidus.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown etiology, seen in children and young adults. Presents as skin-colored shiny papules on the forehead, dorsum of forearms, or shaft of the penis. Histopathological examination shows a characteristic ‘claw clutching the ball’ appearance.
Among the given options lichen planus has purple, pruritic,polygonal lesions; Sacbies has burrow lesion; Scrofuloderma is cutaneous manifestation of TB


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10, 37.11

questions.text:
A migrant worker arrived with complaints of burning urination and urethral discharge following a week of unprotected sex.
Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
• The given picture suggests gonorrhea infection.
  • Many gonorrhoea cases in men are asymptomatic.
  • When present, dysuria or a white, yellow, or green urethral discharge that typically emerges one to fourteen days after infection are among the indications and symptoms of urethral infection in males.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.3

questions.text: Which of the following are tested using Hair perforation test?
questions.solution:
• Dermatophytes, particularly Trichophyton mentagrophytes and its variations, are tested for using a hair perforation test.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.27

questions.text: A patient arrives with the lesion in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Borderline leprosy:

  • The number of skin lesions is in between those of the two polar types. 
  • They could appear as macules, plaques, annular lesions, or odd-looking bands. - characterised by plaques that appear "punched-out." 
  • Lesions are sparser, drier, more insensitive, and contain fewer bacilli in smears and biopsies towards the tuberculoid end of the spectrum than they do towards the lepromatous pole.
Classification Symptoms Disease response
Tuberculoid leprosy A few flat lesions, some large and numb; some nerve involvement Can heal on its own, persist, or may progress to a more severe form
Borderline tuberculoid leprosy Lesions similar to tuberculoid but more numerous; more nerve involvement May persist, revert to tuberculoid, or advance to another form
Mid-borderline leprosy Reddish plaques; moderate numbness; swollen lymph nodes; more nerve involvement May persist, revert to tuberculoid, or advance to another form
Borderline lepromatous leprosy Many lesions, including flat lesions, raised bumps, plaques, and nodules; more numbness May persist, regress, or progress
Lepromatous leprosy Many lesions with bacteria; hair loss; more severe nerve involvement with peripheral nerve thickening; limb weakness; disfigurement Doesn't regress


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10, 28.7, 28.5

questions.text: A young patient has patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling on the scalp. Which of the following investigations will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Tinea capitis, which results from an infection with dermatophytes species, is a common cause of hair loss in youngsters.
  2. Investigations - When examined under a wood light, a yellow-green fluorescence is visible. 
  3. Diagnosis: Fungal Culture after pretreatment with potassium hydroxide.








Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.38, 32.24

questions.text: In which case is granular deposition of IgA at dermal papillae on immunofluorescence most common?
questions.solution:
• Granular deposition of lgA at dermal papillae on immunofluorescence is seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • It is associated with subclinical gluten sensitive enteropathy.
  • Itchy blisters appear in fingers, elbows and knees. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct immunofluorescence microscopy of normal appearing or faintly erythematous perilesional skin (adjacent to active lesion), by demonstration of granular deposits of lgA (with or without complements) in papillary dermis and along the epidermal basement membrane zone.
Below is an image of characteristic lesion seen in DH and its IF.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.52, 50.53

questions.text: A patient came with a history of joint pain and fever for one week. For which the patient took NSAIDs following which she developed a rash and hyperpigmentation on her nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (2) Chikungunya.
  • Based on the clinical history of fever, joint pain, a rash, and the development of brownish discoloration over the nose after one week of taking NSAIDs, the most likely diagnosis is pigmentation due to Chikungunya, a condition where the pigmentation of the nose area is quite noticeable.
  • This pigmentation is not usually seen in other viral exanthems.
  • In contrast, in the case of a fixed drug eruption, the mucocutaneous junction and genital skin, in particular the glans is most often affected, not the nose. (hence, option (3) is incorrect)
Reference Cutaneous manifestations of chikungunya during a recent epidemic in Calicut, north Kerala, south India, IJDVL 2010

questions.text: The following is not a pathological feature of Lichen planus:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Munro's microabscess
Neutrophil predominant micro abscess (Munro microabscess) is seen in Psoriasis.

Lichen planus:
  • Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. 
  • Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, wedge-shaped thickening of the granular layer (responsible for Wickham striae), and compact hyperkeratosis.  
  • Degenerating basal epidermal cells (due to CD8+ Cell-mediated basal cell destruction) are known as colloid bodies (cytoid/Civatte bodies), which may appear singly or in clumps - Characteristic of LP
  • Basal melanocytes may fall into the dermis (pigment incontinence).
  • The rete ridges may have a sawtooth appearance and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max-Joseph spaces.
  • In active LP, a bandlike infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.13, 37.14, 37.3

questions.text: Which glands are affected by bromhidrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Apocrine Sweat Glands

Disorders of the apocrine glands are:
  • Bromhidrosis - abnormal sweat odor due to bacterial growth.
  • Chromhidrosis - secretion of vividly colored apocrine sweat (blue, yellow, or green color). It is usually of apocrine origin and seen in the axilla, areola of the nipple, or face.
  • Fox-Fordyce disease or apocrine miliaria- obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 94.15, 94.16

questions.text: Where is an a 'Hanging Curtain' sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pityriasis rosea
 
  • Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease, probably infective in origin, affecting mainly children and young adults. It is characterized by a distinctive skin eruption and minimal constitutional symptoms.
  • It is also called pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal.
  • The first manifestation of the disease is usually the appearance of the herald patch.
  • Christmas tree pattern along cleavage lines with the peripheral collarette of scale producing the hanging curtain sign is also seen.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.90, 25.91

questions.text: A known case of borderline tuberculoid leprosy was undergoing treatment. Which of the following nerve is commonly affected in such a case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is in favor of leprosy. The most common cranial nerve involved in leprosy is 7th cranial nerve. 
 
  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes.
  • The posterior tibial nerve is most commonly involved, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.
  • The facial nerve is the most frequently affected cranial nerve.
  • Leprosy has a prolonged incubation period, typically ranging from 2 to 12 years. It often presents as a numb area on the skin or a visible skin lesion, which may appear as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule.
  • Lesions typically occur on the face, extensor surfaces of the limbs, trunk, and buttocks. These lesions are associated with impaired nerve function and poor hair growth. Patients may also develop burns or ulcers on the affected anesthetic limb.


Leprosy is classified using two main systems:

  • Ridley-Jopling classification:
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tuberculoid (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
 
  • WHO classification:
    • Paucibacillary
    • Multibacillary



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- II, 9th edition, Page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.13.

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with lesions as shown below.  He had a prodrome of fever, malaise, excruciating burning pain, and later an outbreak of lesions as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem and image showing the dermatomal distribution of lesions point toward Herpes zoster. The classical feature of herpes zoster lesions is their distribution along a dermatome on Chest/Buttock or Face.


Reference : Rook’s Textbook Of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 128.1, 129.1, 25.1 .

questions.text: 25y old male complains of itchy rash over his back. Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Pityriasis Rosea is the most likely lesion. Typically presents with christmas tree lesions having Collarette scales.
Herald Patch -Large and confluent patch seen in thigh, upper arm, Back.
Other named sign - Hanging curtain sign-Marginal Collarette of scale attached peripherally with central winking and atrophy.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 25.91.

questions.text: This finding in the groin region on Wood's lamp examination is seen in
questions.solution:
Coral pink fluorescence in the groin region observed during a Wood's Lamp examination is typically indicative of erythrasma.

This fluorescence occurs due to the presence of porphyrins. The bacterium responsible for erythrasma is Corynebacterium minutissimum, which converts aminolevulinic acid into protoporphyrin, resulting in the characteristic fluorescence.

Other options:

  • Erysipelas: Acute superficial skin infection by Streptococcus, presents with sharply demarcated erythema, no fluorescence under Wood’s lamp.

  • Erysipeloid: Skin infection from Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, usually occupational, affects hands, no Wood’s lamp fluorescence.

  • Ecthyma: Ulcerative form of impetigo, deeper skin involvement, no fluorescence.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?
A  Patch test- Contact dermatitis
B KOH mount – Tinea
C  Biopsy- Lupus Vulgaris
D All of the above
questions.solution:
• All of the following are correctly matched with various investigations done for testing the disease
  • Patch Test - Used to detect Type IV hypersensitivity to antigens that come in contact with skin. Used in diagnosis of Contact dermatitis.
  • KOH mount is used to diagnose Tinea. Branching Hyphae is seen in Tinea Corporis.
  • Lupus vulgaris type of Cutaneous tuberculosis. Characterized by reddish brown Papules. Diagnosis is by Biopsy to look for Caseating Granulomas.
Reference: Lazzarini R, Duarte I, Ferreira AL. Patch tests. An Bras Dermatol. 2013 Nov-Dec;88(6):879-88. doi: 10.1590/abd1806-4841.20132323. PMID: 24474094; PMCID: PMC3900336.

questions.text:
Match the following Wood's lamp findings with the disease:
 
Column I Column II
1 Erythrasma a Yellow fluorescence
2 Pityriasis versicolor b Milky white fluorescence
3 Tinea capitis c Pink fluorescence
4 Vitiligo d Blue fluorescence
e Coral red fluorescence
