The correct match is

1. Erythrasma e)Coral red fluorescence

2. Pityriasis versicolor a)Yellow fluorescence

3. Tinea capitis d)Blue fluorescence

4. Vitiligo b)Milky white florescence


Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 4.20 .

questions.text: A young man presented with painful lesions as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing confluent, red, pustular lesions localized to a single dermatome and associated with severe pain is highly suggestive of herpes zoster, also known as shingles.



Herpes zoster occurs due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which initially causes chickenpox during primary infection. After the initial episode of chickenpox, the virus remains dormant in cranial nerve or dorsal root ganglia. Shingles occurs when the virus reactivates, often many years later, leading to a painful, segmental skin eruption.

Clinical Features:
The first symptom is usually pain, often described as burning, stabbing, or throbbing. This pain may be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness in one or more dermatomes.
The skin eruption typically starts a few days after the onset of pain and involves vesicular lesions confined to the affected dermatome. The most commonly affected dermatomes are thoracic.
The patients are infectious, both from the virus present in the lesions and in the nasopharynx.

Complications:
Zoster is usually self-limiting, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary bacterial infection and post-herpetic neuralgia (chronic pain that can persist after the skin lesions have healed).

Treatment:
For mild infections, analgesia and the treatment of any secondary infections are sufficient.
Antiviral treatment (such as Acyclovir 800 mg) is indicated in certain situations, particularly to reduce the severity, duration, and complications of the infection.
Indications for Antiviral Therapy:
1. Painful zoster infections in adults.
2. Facial zoster at any age (due to the risk of complications like vision or hearing loss).
3. Immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A young girl presented with nocturnal pruritis involving the intertrigonal area and on evaluation the following findings were seen as shown in the image. what is the vector in the given condition
questions.solution:
The given clinical history with the image is suggestive of scabies . It is caused by the itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei.
It is transmitted by direct skin-to-skin contact and less frequently via contaminated clothes and bedding. Clinically, these patients present with superficial excoriated papules or vesicles that are intensely pruritic. They are usually present on the volar surface of the wrists, interdigital spaces, penis, scrotum, navel, and skin folds and creases in the axillae, buttocks, and thigh regions. Burrows may be visualized in the superficial dermis in these regions. Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice applied once, all over the body below the jawline, following a bath.
Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition • Page no: 818, 819

questions.text: What does the Tzanck smear show in a patient with Herpes Labialis?
questions.solution: Tzanck smear in patients with Herpes Labialis shows Multi nucleate giant cells. It is caused by Herpes Simplex Virus type I. Tzanck cells- Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneosly satined ground glass chromatin. It is treated with Oral and Topical Acyclovir. Ref- Fitzpatrick Dermatology 9th edition Page 2721

questions.text: A female presented a few weeks ago to the OPD with an itchy skin rash. She was prescribed a topical ointment that relieved the itching. However, after a few days of stopping the ointment application, she presented to the OPD again with the same complaints. The lesions are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Tinea incognito occurs when a fungal infection (dermatophytosis) is modified by inappropriate use of topical corticosteroids.

  • The patient initially had an itchy rash and was prescribed a topical ointment (likely containing steroids), which relieved the symptoms temporarily.

  • After stopping the ointment, the rash recurs or appears atypical, often with blurred margins, less scaling, or unusual distribution, making it harder to recognize.

  • Key differentiating points:

    • Tinea corporis/cruris: Typical ring-shaped lesions with central clearing and scaling.

    • Psoriasis: Well-demarcated plaques with silvery scales, often symmetrical.

    • Tinea incognito: Atypical, steroid-modified fungal infection.


Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology volume 2 9th edition chapter 32 page no 32.74

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented lesion on his back. On examination, there is a complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hansen’s disease often presents as hypopigmented or erythematous patches with loss of sensation (both fine touch and temperature) due to involvement of peripheral nerves.

  • Leishmaniasis usually presents as chronic ulcerative or nodular skin lesions, not with sensory loss.

  • Psoriasis presents as well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, without sensory loss.

  • Dermatitis (eczema) shows itchy, inflamed skin, also without loss of sensation.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 1384-1386,1388

questions.text: A 7-year-old intellectually disabled boy was brought with large warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet as shown below. Severe fissuring and scaling of the skin are present over the soles. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of large warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet, along with severe fissuring and scaling of the soles, suggests a diagnosis of Norwegian (Crusted) Scabies

Norwegian Scabies

Population at Risk:
  • Individuals with intellectual disabilities, dementia, or Down's syndrome.
  • Immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV or those on immunosuppressive therapy.
Clinical Features:
  • Formation of large, thick crusts, particularly on hands and feet.
  • Palms and soles may appear fissured and thickened.
  • Scalp, face, and areas of seborrhea may show erythema and scaling.
  • Absence of itching due to inadequate immune response.
Diagnosis:
  • Skin scrapings revealing numerous mites and eggs confirm the condition.
Management:
  • Oral ivermectin is the first-line treatment.
  • Topical scabicides may also be used.
  • Keratolytic agents to manage crusting.
Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no 34.42-34.47

choices.text: Bacterial growth or culture on selective media

questions.text: After engaging in sexual activity with a new partner, a 25-year-old woman who is sexually active complains of purulent discharge and dysuria. The most sensitive diagnostic investigation is:
questions.solution:
• It is a case of sexually transmitted urethritis which can be Gonococcal or Non-gonococcal and NAAT of the first-catch urine is the diagnostic test of choice and is the most sensitive diagnostic test out of the following for the same.
  • NAATs are primarily used to detect Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Testing can be performed on urine samples or swabs from the urethra, cervix, or other relevant sites.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.7, 30.13

questions.text: The following itching lesion has been present on a young man for one month. Except for ____  all of the following genera can result in this form of lesion:
questions.solution:
• The lesions shown in the image are suggestive of Tinea cruris, commonly known as Jack itch, is a dermatophytosis of the groin area typically caused by Trichophyton rubrum. 
  • A class of fungus known as dermatophytes includes ringworms which, under moist conditions, can infect and thrive solely on dead keratin, the outermost layer of skin, hair, and nails.
  • It belongs to three genera Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 31.26, 32.3

questions.text: The wife of a long-distance truck driver engages in sexual activity and has vaginal discharge. Which medication should be administered in the Syndromic Approach?
questions.solution:
• Metronidazole and Fluconazole are commonly used in the syndromal management of vaginal discharge.
  • Metronidazole is a antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections, including those caused by anaerobic bacteria, while Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections, such as yeast infections.
  • Together they can be used to treat the symptoms of a vaginal discharge.
According to syndromic management its secnidazole plus fluconazole but since the question does not have that answer for vaginal discharge, we can use metronidazole instead of secnidazole.



STI KITs Memorizing Technique-
Kit 1- Grey- Oldage people have grey hair and have urogenital dysfunction- Urogenital discharge
Kit 2- Green- Sanitary pads come in green package- Vaginal discharge
Kit 3- White- Non herpetic ulcer penicillin
Kit 4- Blue- Non herpetic ulcer penicillin hypersensitive
Kit 5- Red- Herpetic ulcers have a red base- Herpetic ulcer
Kit 6- YeLOW- LOWer abdominal pain
Kit 7- Black- Bubo, inguinal



Reference- Shaw’s textbook of Gynaecology Page no 364,365

questions.text: Warts on the penis of a sexually active male were discovered, as seen below. Which of these HPV strains is mostly involved in these lesions?
questions.solution:
The picture suggests it to be a case of Anogenital warts on penis, which are caused by low-risk HPV viruses
i.e. HPV- 6 and 11.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.56, 25.58

questions.text: A 5 years old girl presented with lesion on the face for the last 3 months. A skin biopsy was performed and the findings are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The biopsy is showing Molluscum Bodies seen typically in Molluscum contagiosum.
  • This disease is usually seen in young children (like in this case) and causes lesions on the face which are pearly white papules.
  • There may be a history of transmission from mother as well.
  • Also called as HP Bodies( Henderson-Paterson bodies ), these are intracytoplasmic, eosinophilic, granular inclusions within the keratinocytes of the basal, spinous, and granular layers of the epidermis.



Reference : Rook’s tex ok no Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume 2 Chapter 25 fig25.12

questions.text: Which of the following will produce painful ulcers on the glans tip
questions.solution:
• Chancroid presents with a painful genital ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Can have single or multiple ulcers.
  • The incubation period is 3-10 days.
  • The primary lesion begins as a painful papule that undergoes central necrosis to form painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges.
  • Kissing ulcers due to autoinoculation may also be present.
  • It is associated with painful lymphadenopathy, which later progresses to form suppurating buboes and sinuses.
  • Other options: Herpes genitalis is characterized by painful vesicular lesions that progress to ulcers in the genital region, caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). U=Multiple ulcers are seen. It is usually associated with localized tender lymphadenopathy. LGV will present will painless ulcers. Gonorrhea would not usually present with ulcers.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.21

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding chancroid?
questions.solution:
• Groove sign of Greenblatt is not seen in chancroid, it is seen in LGV.

Chancroids are caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Their features include:
i. School of fish/ rail road track appearance
ii. Bleeds on touch (soft sore)
iii. Painful, non-ulcerative ulcer



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.20, 30.22

questions.text:
STD visit by young male with this painful lesion present in genital area.
What will not be seen in the corresponding microscopy:
questions.solution:
• Cytology of herpes group of viruses include the following features:
  1. Multinucleated cells
  2. Tzanck cell : Enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei present in large, round keratinocytes with peripheral halo.
  3. Greenblatt and Pund cells : A large mononuclear cell whose nucleus is eccentrically placed.
  4. HP bodies : Intracytoplasmic viral inclusion bodies, eosinophilic in nature and seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.14, 3.26

choices.text: Don't involve in sexual intercourse when an active lesion present
Give prophylactic antiviral to the husband also
Give antiviral whenever the lesion is present

questions.text: Despite her husband being wart-free, the woman has active, recurrent genital warts. What suggestions do you have for preventing transmission?
questions.solution:
• Advice given to prevent transmission is option A- Don’t involve in sexual intercourse when active lesion is present
  • Other options are usually not advisable

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 31.24

questions.text:
A patient with painful lesions that were grouped together came to the STD clinic.
Which of the subsequent tests ought to be carried out to make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tzanck smear for multinucleate giant cells

 
  • Genital herpes is more commonly caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) 2. The patients present with painful vesicular-ulcerative lesions. In men, it occurs mainly on the penis or urethra. In women, the cervix, vagina, vulva, and perineum can be involved. 
  • Herpes infection can be caused by HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes.
  • The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. 
  • The Tzanck smear technique is a rapid and inexpensive diagnostic method. Scrapings (preferably from the base of vesicles) are obtained from the lesions and stained with a  1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. 
  • Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, known as Tzanck cells, are seen. Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles in Giemsa-stained smears.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 31.22, 31.23

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is included in the syndromic management of genital ulcer syndrome in India?
questions.solution:
The syndromic management of genital ulcer syndrome in India includes chancroid, primary chancre and herpes simplex.




Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK572660/

questions.text: What treatment should be given to a patient with asymptomatic macules and an erythematous, painless lesion over the glans with generalised lymphadenopathy?
questions.solution:
• Treatment of choice in this condition is benzathine penicillin.
  • A young man with generalised lymphadenopathy and asymptomatic macules, papules, and a reddish patch across his palate, as well as a flat, moist lesion on his glans penis, all suggestive of syphilis.
  •  Injection Benzathine penicillin is first line of treatment for syphilis.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 29.25

questions.text: A known case of HIV is taking HAART. How to evaluate efficacy of treatment?
questions.solution:
The evaluation of efficacy of HAART in a case of HIV is done with the help of viral load. 
 

In a known case of HIV undergoing Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART), the efficacy of the treatment is primarily evaluated by measuring the viral load. This is the amount of HIV RNA present in the blood.

  • Viral load: The main indicator of treatment efficacy. If HAART is effective, the viral load should decrease significantly over time and ideally become undetectable (usually <20-50 copies/ml). A decrease in viral load indicates that the treatment is working to suppress the virus. Monitoring viral load helps assess how well the antiretroviral therapy is controlling the virus.

Other options:
 

  • ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay): This is primarily used for HIV screening and not for evaluating the efficacy of HAART. It detects HIV antibodies but doesn't provide direct information about viral replication or treatment success.

  • p24 antigen: This test detects a core protein of HIV and can be used in early HIV infection (before antibodies develop), but it's not routinely used to assess the efficacy of HAART in an established HIV infection.

  • Western blot: This is a confirmatory test for HIV infection after an initial positive screening test (e.g., ELISA). It's not used to assess the effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1560, 1595, 1596.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of multiple sexual partners presented with a single well defined perineal painless ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The sexually active female with a history of multiple sexual partners is at risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection.
The development of a painless ulcer (Hunterian chancre) and non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests primary syphilis.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 29.10, 29.15.

questions.text: A female patient, who is the wife of a truck driver with multiple sexual partners presents with vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination, cervical erosions are noted. Which colored kit will be prescribed to the patient?
questions.solution:
• The female patient has likely contracted a sexually transmitted infection from her partner who has multiple sexual partners.
  • Syndromic management for her STI would be followed 
  • In the given scenario - she has vaginal discharge along with presence of cervical erosions - hence, she should be considered a case of CERVICITIS. (not vaginitis)
Hence, the female must be treated for cervicitis based on the algorithm:
  • She should thus be treated with the Grey kit.
  • This kit contains a single tablet of 1 gram azithromycin for chlamydia and a single tablet of 400 mg cefixime for gonorrhea.
  • As a rule, partner treatment is also advised in patients of cervicitis.


Reference: Gupta V, Sharma VK. Syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections: A critical appraisal and the road ahead. Natl Med J India 2019;32:147-152

questions.text: Inguinal bubo is caused by which of the microorganisms?
questions.solution:
Inguinal bubo refers to painful enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes, usually following a genital ulcer.

Key points:

  • Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection:

    • Presents with: Painful genital ulcer + tender inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo)

  • Other organisms:

    • Corynebacterium diphtheriae: Causes diphtheria (respiratory or cutaneous)

    • Klebsiella granulomatis: Causes donovanosis (painless genital ulcer, no bubo)

    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Causes urethritis, cervicitis, septic arthritis; inguinal bubo is rare

questions.text: A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
Bacterial vaginosis is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobic bacteria due to a loss of normal lactobacilli. It presents with a thin, grayish-white, fishy-smelling vaginal discharge. Vaginal itching or irritation is usually absent or minimal, which differentiates it from Candida infection where itching is marked.

Diagnosis is made using Amsel’s criteria, which include:

  1. Thin, homogeneous discharge

  2. Vaginal pH > 4.5

  3. Positive whiff test (fishy odor on adding KOH)

  4. Presence of clue cells on microscopy

Treatment is with oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days.

questions.text: Which of the following is not found in gonorrhea
questions.solution:
Gonorrhoea is unlikely cause of Genital Ulcer
  • Gonorrhoea is caused by a gram negative diplococci- Neisseria gonorrhoea. infection begins in the cervix uteri and urethra and may spread to the Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • The vaginal mucosa is usually unaffected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to cocci infection and also because vaginal secretions have an acidic pH.
  • Complications include: urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease, chronic pelvic pain, infertility, first-trimester abortion, and ectopic pregnancy, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, liver capsule inflammation with resultant intra-abdominal adhesions.
  • Complications specific to males include epididymitis, prostatitis, and proctitis, Infections in the periurethral tissues can lead to abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).
  • On evaluation of discharge of gram stain shows an intracellular gram negative diplococci. Stuart's transport medium is used. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250 mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose, or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 235-237.

questions.text: A 28-year-old truck driver presents with a single painless ulcer over his penis following unprotected sex on evaluation he was found to have an ulcer with clean base and raised, firm, border and painless lymphadenopathy. What could be the possible diagnosis
questions.solution: Single painless ulcer with clean base and raised, firm, border, painless lymphadenopathy is suggestive of syphilis. Syphilis is a systemic bacterial infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum. The classic primary syphilis clinical presentation is a solitary nontender genital chancre in response to invasion by the T pallidum. The incubation period before the primary chancre manifestations is about 10 to 90 days, with a median of 21 to 25 day. secondary syphilis result from hematogenous dissemination of the infection and are protean: condyloma lata (papulosquamous eruption), lesions on the hands and feet, macular rash, diffuse lymphadenopathy, headache, myalgia, arthralgia, pharyngitis, hepatosplenomegaly, alopecia, and malaise. Both primary and secondary lesions resolve without treatment, and the patient enters either an early or latent phase in which no clinical manifestations are present. The infection can only be detected at this stage with serological testing. Some patients in this stage will progress to the tertiary stage, characterized by cardiovascular syphilis, late neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis, syphilitic paresis), and late benign syphilis. Ref- Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition page 30.21

choices.text: Defect in the formation of disulfide bonds

questions.text: The following is not a feature of Netherton syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Autosomal dominant inheritance
 
  • Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of cornification caused by mutations in the serine protease inhibitor of Kazal type 5 gene (SPINK5), which encodes a serine protease inhibitor expressed in epithelial and mucosal surfaces
  • Hair shaft analysis of NS patients finds a reduced number of S-S disulfide bonds in cortical fibers.
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata or bamboo hair is characterized by invagination of the distal hair shaft into the proximal portion. It is seen in Netherton's syndrome. It is also called golf-tee or ball and socket appearance 
  • Bamboo hair presents with atopy, recurrent skin infections, and an increased risk of skin cancer. 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.53, 68.3

questions.text: The following is not associated with exfoliative dermatitis:
questions.solution:
• Eczematous Dermatitis: Includes atopic dermatitis and contact dermatitis (both allergic and irritant).

  • Psoriasis: Generalized psoriasis, especially pustular psoriasis.

  • Drug Reactions: Adverse effects from medications like antibiotics, anticonvulsants, or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

  • Fungal Infections: Such as tinea (ringworm) affecting large areas of skin.

  • Viral Infections: Infections like herpes simplex or viral exanthems.

  • Autoimmune Diseases: Conditions like SLE or dermatomyositis.

  • Lymphoma and Other Malignancies: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma can present with exfoliative dermatitis.

  • Nutritional Deficiencies: Deficiencies in zinc or essential fatty acids.

  • Seborrheic Dermatitis: Severe cases can lead to widespread scaling and redness.

  • Environmental Irritants: Exposure to harsh chemicals or extreme sunburn



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 39.31,147.23

questions.text: Which of the following are not cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Gorlin’s sign

Gorlin’s sign is the ability of patients of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle.
The following are various manifestations of dermatomyositis:
  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints, as shown in the image below
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of the eyelid with periorbital edema
  • Gottron's sign: Symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques, often atrophic, in the same distribution as Gottron's papules
  • Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema, across the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution)
  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 53.4, 53.5

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with ash leaf spots, adenoma sebaceum and epilepsy . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tuberous sclerosis (TSC-1 & TSC-2) is also known as Bourneville disease. characterized clinically by variable neuropsychiatric manifestations that range from intractable epilepsy (including infantile spasms, which occur in as many as 20-30% of TSC infants) to intellectual disability and autism and are often the defining and/or presenting feature of the illness. Common neurological symptoms of TSC include:

Brain tumors—The three types of brain lesions seen in TSC are:
(1) cortical tubers.
(2) Subependymal nodules.
(3) Subependymal giant-cell astrocytomas
Other types of tumors can occur in the hearts of infants and young children with TSC (called rhabdomyomas) and in the eyes (called phakomas).
Other neurological features include. (1) seizures.
(2) Autism Spectrum Disorder.
(3) Cognitive difficulties.
(4) behavioural disturbances.
Skin abnormalities vary widely in individuals with Tuberous sclerosis. (1) Hypomelanic macules ("ash leaf spots").
(2) Facial angiofibromas (also known as adenoma sebaceum).
(3) Shagreen patches.
(4)Ungual or subungual fibromas.
(5) Forehead plaques.
Genitourinary features -Cysts and Angiomyolipomas.
Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition • Page 801 - 807

questions.text: A patient presents with joint pain which increases in the early morning when he wakes up and decreases with activity. Examination reveals the following picture (given below) along with inflammation of the wrist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Morning stiffness that improves with activity indicates inflammatory arthritis, which includes psoriatic arthritis.

  • Wrist involvement along with the pattern seen in the picture (likely showing dactylitis, joint swelling, or nail changes) points toward psoriatic arthritis.

  • Psoriatic arthritis can involve small and large joints, often asymmetrically, and is associated with psoriatic skin or nail lesions.

  • Reactive arthritis usually follows infection and commonly affects lower limb joints, sometimes with enthesitis or conjunctivitis.

  • Osteoarthritis typically causes pain worsening with activity, with brief morning stiffness.

  • Pseudogout usually presents as acute monoarthritis, most commonly in the knee or wrist, and is associated with calcium pyrophosphate deposition.


Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no 35.26

questions.text: Which of the following side effects are seen most commonly with Isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid) is a highly teratogenic drug used in the treatment of severe nodulocystic acne.

Most common and serious side effect:

  • Retinoic acid embryopathy (also called Isotretinoin embryopathy)

    Features of Isotretinoin Embryopathy:

  • Craniofacial anomalies: Microtia/anotia, hypertelorism, cleft palate

  • Cardiac defects: Conotruncal anomalies (e.g., Tetralogy of Fallot, transposition)

  • Central nervous system defects: Hydrocephalus, microcephaly

  • Thymic hypoplasia

    Incorrect options:

  • Ebstein’s anomaly – Classically associated with lithium, not isotretinoin.

  • Neural tube defects – More commonly associated with valproate, folate deficiency.

  • Discoloration of teeth – Classically caused by tetracyclines, not isotretinoin.


Reference:Williams Obstetrics 25th edition page no 540-543

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with the following lesion.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinoma is strongly suggested by a lesion  with raised, pearly borders, a central crust, and telangiectasia on the lesion's surface.
  • Typically, basal cell carcinomas appear as pearly papules with dilated, noticeable subepidermal blood vessels (telangiectasias). Some cancers have melanin and resemble melanocytic nevi or melanomas on the surface.
  • After years of neglect or in extremely aggressive tumours, advanced lesions may ulcerate and cause considerable local invasion of the bone or face sinuses, which explains the outdated name "rodent ulcers."


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 141.9, 141.10

questions.text: A 70 years old patient presents with a lesion on the cheek with raised, pearly borders and with telangiectasias on surface of the lesion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The description above is typical of Basal cell carcinoma, which most commonly appears as a pearly white, dome-shaped papule with prominent telangiectatic surface vessels. Pathognomonic histology: Islands and lobules of Basaloid cells which palisade in the periphery.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma most commonly appears as a firm, smooth, or hyperkeratotic papule or plaque, often with central ulceration.HPE- Keratin Pearls


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 141.8,141.9

questions.text: Older man with a face mole that has been present for a while but is now growing larger and displaying irregular borders. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Macroscopic features in naevi suggestive of a malignant melanoma might include: change in size, shape, colour, thickness, presence of satellite lesions, and discharge.
  • Superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) is the most common presentation, with gradual onset and then rapid growth within the months preceding presentation.
  • There may be nodularity within SSM, which is indicative of the onset of the vertical growth phase.
  • Other signs may include itching, tingling, and serosanguinous discharge, although these tend to appear late in the process.

Reference :Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 143.9

questions.text: Which disease is represented by the mnemonic ABCDEF?
questions.solution:
Malignant melanoma is diagnosed based on the following characteristics-ABCDE
  Asymmetrical pigmented nodule
  Border irregularity: scallops and notches are seen in nodules.
  Color variability: striking feature
  Diameter: size is more than 6 mm
  Evolution
  • Excise all doubtful lesions for histopathological examination.
  • Using a microscopic micrometre, Breslow's  approach measures the vertical distance (in mm) from the granular cell layer to the deepest section of the tumour.


Reference :Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 143.8, 143.7

questions.text: What would be the classification of a malignant melanoma that did not invade the subcutaneous tissue but instead impinges into the reticular dermis(not invading reticular dermis)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Clarks level III
  • Clark's system is based on the layer of skin invaded by melanoma.
  •  Breslow thickness has largely supplanted Clark's as it is a more accurate method of predicting prognosis.
Malignant melanoma which fills the papillary dermis, impinging on the reticular dermis but not invading is classified as Clarks level III, based on the depth of invasion.

Malignant melanoma:
 
  • Both Breslow's and Clark’s systems are used to stage melanoma on the basis of depth of invasion.
Clark’s Classification:


Breslow's classification:



Reference- https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/def/clark-level-iv-skin-cancer

questions.text: A child present with the following condition. The patient at the risk of malignancy in the future?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a child with an extensive black, heterogeneous, hairy palpable lesion on the left side of the face involving both the upper and lower eyelids.
The findings are suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus, specifically, a giant melanocytic nevus.
Especially in large congenital nevi, there is a risk for transformation to malignant melanoma.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 75.10, 143.7.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with swelling on the hard palate as shown. Which of the following is the most common condition causing this?
questions.solution:
The HIV positive patient with multiple, firm-appearing violaceous plaques on the hard palate is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, a multifocal epithelial tumor attributed to HPV-8 infection.
  • KS is considered an AIDS-defining illness.
  • The intraoral site most commonly affected is the palate followed by the gingiva.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 520, 522.

questions.text: 50y old male came to your OPD with the following lesion. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Given image shows central ulcer with raised borders and rolled out edges suggestive of Basal Cell Cancer.
Slow growing Malignant Tumor which is locally invasive, UV radiation is the strongest predisposing factor.
Affects elderly male with excessive skin exposure.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 651.

questions.text: A baby presents to the OPD and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a capillary hemangioma affecting the left upper eyelid and periocular area. Capillary hemangioma is the most prevalent tumor in the orbit and periorbital region in children.



A hemangioma is a benign tumor resulting from the abnormal proliferation of blood vessels. The different types of hemangiomas include:

Capillary hemangioma (most common)
Juvenile or strawberry hemangioma
Cavernous hemangioma
Pyogenic hemangioma
Clinical Presentation:
Capillary hemangiomas can appear as small isolated lesions or as larger masses that may lead to:

Visual impairment (due to mechanical ptosis and subsequent sensory deprivation amblyopia)
Systemic complications (such as severe thrombocytopenia)
Association with PHACE syndrome (which includes Posterior fossa anomalies, Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, and Eye or Endocrine abnormalities)
Indications for Treatment:
Treatment is indicated for the following reasons:

Visual issues (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus)
Cosmetic concerns
Compression of the optic nerve
Exposure keratopathy
Treatment Options:
Capillary hemangiomas frequently undergo spontaneous regression. However, treatment options may include:

Beta-blockers: Oral propranolol or topical timolol
Steroids: Intralesional triamcinolone or betamethasone, topical clobetasol, and systemic steroids
Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine for lesions that threaten vision and are resistant to steroids
Local resection using cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser

questions.text: An 7 year-old child born with normal skin began to have skin pigmentation over sun exposed areas at 2 years of age and later developed multiple skin tumors . The workup revealed defective nucleotide excision repair. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of skin tumors with defective DNA nucleotide excision repair is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum.
Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair where there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.
UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In Xeroderma pigmentosa There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused, by UV exposure.
Lippincott's Illustrated biochemisty 6th Edition • Page no 408

questions.text: A female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• how asymmetry, irregular borders, color variegation, and rapid enlargement.

  • Key features (ABCDE rule):

    • A – Asymmetry: One half does not match the other half.

    • B – Border irregularity: Edges are ragged or blurred.

    • C – Color variation: Multiple shades of brown, black, or even red, white, or blue.

    • D – Diameter: Usually >6 mm.

    • E – Evolving: Change in size, shape, or color over time.

  • Basal cell carcinoma: Usually pearly, non-pigmented nodules with telangiectasia; slow-growing.

  • Squamous cell carcinoma: Often a scaly, crusted lesion, may ulcerate, less pigmented.

  • Malignant nevus: Less commonly shows rapid evolution or significant asymmetry like melanoma.



Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology page no 4.20-4.21,144.1,144.2,144.5

questions.text: The picture depicts a 25-year-old woman who has erythematous papules on her face. Excessive perspiration, exposure to the sun, and emotional distress all made the lesions worse. Description fits with:
questions.solution:
The above clinical description with worsening of lesions on excessive perspiration/sun exposure/emotional distress fits with Rosacea. 

Rosacea
1.  It's a centro-facial disease, especially seen on the convexities of the face (cheeks, chin, forehead, and nose).
2. The exact cause of rosacea is not known but may be associated with an abnormal vascular reactivity (exaggerated flushing response to heat, spicy food, alcohol, and stress) without any pharmacological defect.


Reference :Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 91.6

questions.text: A young girl who had experienced spotty hair loss for two weeks presented to the OPD as depicted below. Both erythema and scarring were absent. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Trichotillomania
  • The given image shows patchy hair loss with hair of various lengths pointing towards a diagnosis of trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is non scarring alopecia characterised by perifollicular haemorrhage.
  • Trichotillomania is a disorder characterized by the compulsive pulling of hair.
  • It is predominantly seen in females and is almost always associated with psychological or behavioral stress disorders like OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder), Body dysmorphic disorder, intellectual disability, etc. 
  • It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern.
  • The hairs are often twisted and broken at varying lengths or may be present as uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.
  • Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example - eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.
  • Patients sometimes may swallow/eat the hair and present in intestinal obstruction. (Bezoar)

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.17, 86.18

questions.text:
A boy had itchy, excoriated papules on the forehead and the exposed parts of the arms and legs for 3 years.
The disease was at its worst during the rainy season and completely disappeared during the winter. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Insect bite hypersensitivity (Paederus dermatitis) causes an itchy, excoriated (scratchy) rash on the body when the affected person is bitten by certain insects. In this case, the young boy had itchy, scratchy papules (raised bumps) on his forehead, arms, and legs for three years, with the worst symptoms in the rainy season and complete remission (temporary improvement) in the winter season. This suggests that the boy's skin reactivity to certain insect bites, predominantly in the rainy season, is causing his symptoms. Treatment for insect bite hypersensitivity usually involves antihistamines, topical steroids, and avoiding future insect bites.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 117.11

questions.text: A female patient, age 24, has patchy baldness in the right temporal and occipital region. Upon examination, many little broken hairs and non-scarring alopecia were discovered. Scalp scrapings revealed peri-follicular bleeding, minor lymphocytic infiltration, and moderate inflammation. Which diagnosis is the most likely?
questions.solution:
• Trichotillomania (TTM), commonly referred to as the "hair pulling disorder," is an impulse control condition that is characterized by a persistent urge that causes hair pulling.
  • This happens to the point that the patient exhibits alopecia.
  • Hair pulling may occur at any site, although the head, pubic region and the area around the eyes are the most common.
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages could be seen on dermoscopy. 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.17

questions.text:
A girl presents with a developing mass on the left side of her neck which is firm in consistency.On her face and trunk, she had flat patches and hyperpigmented lesions that may vary in color from light brown to dark brown and axillary freckling. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical description with flat patches/brown hyperpigmented lesions on the trunk which are likely Cafe-Au Lait macules and Axillary freckling point towards a diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis.
  • Individuals with Neurofibromatosis are prone to develop neurofibromas(neuronal tumors), particularly in the head and neck region which again goes with the clinical picture.
  • Cystic Hygroma/Lipoma - Don't have firm consistency - they are cystic(Cystic hygroma)/rubbery(lipoma) in consistency.

Axillary freckling in neurofibromatosis. 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 80.3,75.16

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of the following condition?
questions.solution:
• Fluocinolone is a steroid and is not used in the treatment of acne as steroids can exacerbate acne.
  • Treatment includes topical retinoids and anti-bacterial depending on the grade/severity of disease.


Reference:Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37, 90.38, 90.40

questions.text: Identify this condition:
questions.solution:
The picture displays bluish, bulging masses that represent enlarged veins in the anal region. It seems to allude to hemorrhoids.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue found in the anal canal that contain smooth muscle fibers, venules, and arterioles. Depending on where they are, they can be divided into internal and external hemorrhoids.

Reference: Bailey's and love short practice of surgery 28th edition page no 1409

questions.text: Which of the following is not an alopecia areata association for a patient with focal alopecia areata?
questions.solution:
• Alopecia areata commonly presents as bald, round or oval patches without scarring.
  • Hairs at the margins may be visible, with other presentations including total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis), loss of scalp and body hair (alopecia universalis), or a band-like pattern along the scalp.
  • Regrowth may initially be grey or white, but usually repigmentation is seen in a few weeks or months.
  • Nail abnormalities can also be seen including pitting, roughness, brittleness and separation.
  • Geographic tongue is not a feature.


Reference :Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.31

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complains about being bald. Examination revealed distinct bald areas without any scars. Small broken hairs were detected in the surrounding area. What is the plausible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Alopecia areata
  • Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss.
  • Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease.
  • Alopecia areata preferentially targets pigmented hair. Older patients with grey hair have a mixture of white and pigmented hair.
  • If the disease progresses rapidly, only pigmented hair will be affected, sparing the white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair color that is called going white overnight.
  • Other options:
  • Telogen effluvium leads to diffuse hair loss that affects all hair equally, not just pigmented hair. So, overall hair color will not be affected.
  • Androgenetic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fiber production by follicles and miniaturization. It is of two types , male pattern and female pattern hair loss. Male pattern hair loss may occur in female & vice versa is also true. Male pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.
  • Alopecia after chemotherapy is known as anagen effluvium. Hair loss following chemotherapy usually occurs within 1–3 weeks after initiation of the therapy. In this type of hair loss, the anagen phase is abruptly terminated. This leads to the loss of dystrophic or broken hairs and the condition is called anagen effluvium.

Reference:Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.31

questions.text: For the past two years, a 17-year-old girl with acne has been taking a medication. She now displays blue-black nail coloration. The medicine that most likely caused the pigmentation mentioned above is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Minocycline
 
  • The above clinical scenario of melanonychia with the pigmentation of nail fold which is called the Hutchinson's sign. 
  • It is seen in subungual melanoma.
  • In benign nail pigmentation due to drugs (eg. minocycline) or injury (hematoma), the colour stays within the margins of the nail plate and doesn't extend to nail folds.




Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10243409/

questions.text: The oral cavity of a young woman is filled with white lacy lesions, and her proximal nail fold has spread onto the nail bed. What possible diagnosis is there
questions.solution:
• Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder affecting the skin and mucosal membranes. Nail involvement includes exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depression.
  • It manifests as 6Ps pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques.
  • It also exhibits Wickham striae (thin white lacy lines on the lesion), and the Koebner phenomenon (new lesions at sites of skin trauma).
  • Mucosal involvement is common including mouth and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.1, 37.3

questions.text: Identify the DOC for a condition where a 10 year old child presents with patches of hair loss. Magnifying glass examination shows black spots on the loss area .
questions.solution:
Griseofulvin is the drug of choice for the treatment of Tinea capitis.





Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.40

questions.text: Below is an image of Hair shaft. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Image given is the paintbrush appearance seen in Trichorrhexis nodosa.
  • Trichorrhexis nodosa is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily.
  • It is associated with underlying disorders in some cases such as argininosuccinic aciduria, Menkes' kinky hair syndrome, Netherton's syndrome, and hypothyroidism.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 89.54

questions.text:
A girl child was seen with the following lesion associated with dry eyes, and night blindness .
What does the dermatological finding in the picture represent?
questions.solution:
• This is a Phrynoderma case.
  • A type of follicular hyperkeratosis called phrynoderma is connected to nutritional deficits.
  • Although uncommon in developed nations, it is endemic among poor populations.
Nicholls first used the term "phrynoderma" to describe the "toad-like" appearance of the skin of malnourished labourers in 1933.
Isolated vitamin A, B complex, C, and E deficiency can result in this type of dermatosis

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 87.14

questions.text: A patient presented with pitting of nails, subungual hyperkeratosis and oil drop changes. Clinical image is shown below. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Irregular pitting of nails, subungal hyperkeratosis and oil drop changes are seen in psoriasis. 




Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- II, 9th edition, Page no 35.1, 35.8, 35.9, 35.10.

questions.text: A female presented to the Dermatology OPD with the complaints of hair loss for 3 weeks. She had a history of COVID-19 infection 3 months back. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and image is telogen effluvium. 
 
  • It is a non scarring type of alopecia with marked diffuse shedding of normal hair due to premature termination of anagen phase of hair cycle. 
  • It is usually seen 2-3 months after stressful events such as surgery, fever. It resolves spontaneously. 


Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Volume- III, 9th edition, Page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of Non Scarring Alopecia, except?
questions.solution:
Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a primary cicatricial condition which is scarring alopecia affecting Post Menopausal Woman frequently over the eyebrows.
Other causes for Scarring Alopecia -Scleroderma, Favus, Kerion, Lupus Vulgaris, Discoid lupus.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page. No- 89.28, 89.31, 37.1.

questions.text:
Consider the causes of alopecia. Which among the following cause(s) non-scarring alopecia?
A. Alopecia areata
B. Telogen effluvium
C. Androgenic alopecia
D. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Non-scarring alopecia can result from conditions such as androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium. Frontal fibrosing alopecia, on the other hand, is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

Alopecia areata is a chronic, T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease that leads to non-scarring hair loss. It is associated with autoimmune conditions like thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. While it predominantly affects the scalp, it can also impact areas such as the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In more severe cases, it can progress to complete scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis) or total body hair loss (alopecia universalis).

Telogen effluvium is another form of non-scarring alopecia characterized by diffuse shedding of normal hair. This occurs due to the premature end of the anagen (growth) phase of the hair cycle and can be acute or chronic.

Acute telogen effluvium typically occurs 2-3 months after a stressful event, such as a high fever, surgery, significant blood loss, or severe malnutrition. Hormonal changes postpartum can also trigger it (telogengravidarum). While it may cause a noticeable reduction in hair density, it does not result in total baldness and usually resolves on its own.

Chronic telogen effluvium refers to the diffuse shedding of telogen-phase hair for more than six months. Common causes include thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, and malnutrition.


Androgenetic alopecia is a condition characterized by decreased hair fiber production and follicle miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), an androgenic metabolite, plays a key role in its development. It presents in two forms: male-pattern and female-pattern hair loss. Male-pattern hair loss involves frontal hairline recession and thinning at the vertex, while female-pattern hair loss causes diffuse thinning in the mid-frontal scalp, with little to no involvement of the temporal region.


Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 32.24,32.39,32.40,86.17,89.6,89.7,89.14,89.17,89,20,89.24,89.25,89.46 .
